summary.long: Genesis is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the earth was without shape and empty, and darkness was over the surface of the watery deep, but the Spirit of God was moving over the surface of the water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let there be light.” And there was light!
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God saw that the light was good, so God separated the light from the darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God called the light “day” and the darkness “night.” There was evening, and there was morning, marking the first day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let there be an expanse in the midst of the waters and let it separate water from water.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So God made the expanse and separated the water under the expanse from the water above it. It was so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God called the expanse “sky.” There was evening, and there was morning, a second day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let the water under the sky be gathered to one place and let dry ground appear.” It was so.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God called the dry ground “land” and the gathered waters he called “seas.” God saw that it was good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let the land produce vegetation: plants yielding seeds and trees on the land bearing fruit with seed in it, according to their kinds.” It was so.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The land produced vegetation—plants yielding seeds according to their kinds, and trees bearing fruit with seed in it according to their kinds. God saw that it was good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was evening, and there was morning, a third day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let there be lights in the expanse of the sky to separate the day from the night, and let them be signs to indicate seasons and days and years,
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: and let them serve as lights in the expanse of the sky to give light on the earth.” It was so.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God made two great lights—the greater light to rule over the day and the lesser light to rule over the night. He made the stars also.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God placed the lights in the expanse of the sky to shine on the earth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to preside over the day and the night, and to separate the light from the darkness. God saw that it was good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was evening, and there was morning, a fourth day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let the water swarm with swarms of living creatures and let birds fly above the earth across the expanse of the sky.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God created the great sea creatures and every living and moving thing with which the water swarmed, according to their kinds, and every winged bird according to its kind. God saw that it was good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God blessed them and said, “Be fruitful and multiply and fill the water in the seas, and let the birds multiply on the earth.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: There was evening, and there was morning, a fifth day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Let the land produce living creatures according to their kinds: cattle, creeping things, and wild animals, each according to its kind.” It was so.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God made the wild animals according to their kinds, the cattle according to their kinds, and all the creatures that creep along the ground according to their kinds. God saw that it was good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God said, “Let us make humankind in our image, after our likeness, so they may rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air, over the cattle, and over all the earth, and over all the creatures that move on the earth.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
God created humankind in his own image,
in the image of God he created them,
male and female he created them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God blessed them and said to them, “Be fruitful and multiply! Fill the earth and subdue it! Rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air and every creature that moves on the ground.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Then God said, “I now give you every seed-bearing plant on the face of the entire earth and every tree that has fruit with seed in it. They will be yours for food.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: And to all the animals of the earth, and to every bird of the air, and to all the creatures that move on the ground—everything that has living breath in it—I give every green plant for food.” It was so.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God saw all that he had made—and it was very good! There was evening, and there was morning, the sixth day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The heavens and the earth were completed with everything that was in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By the seventh day God finished the work that he had been doing, and he ceased on the seventh day all the work that he had been doing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God blessed the seventh day and made it holy because on it he ceased all the work that he had been doing in creation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the account of the heavens and the earth when they were created—when the Lord God made the earth and heavens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now no shrub of the field had yet grown on the earth, and no plant of the field had yet sprouted, for the Lord God had not caused it to rain on the earth, and there was no man to cultivate the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Springs would well up from the earth and water the whole surface of the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God formed the man from the soil of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and the man became a living being.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God planted an orchard in the east, in Eden; and there he placed the man he had formed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God made all kinds of trees grow from the soil, every tree that was pleasing to look at and good for food. (Now the tree of life and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil were in the middle of the orchard.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a river flows from Eden to water the orchard, and from there it divides into four headstreams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The name of the first is Pishon; it runs through the entire land of Havilah, where there is gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The gold of that land is pure; pearls and lapis lazuli are also there).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The name of the second river is Gihon; it runs through the entire land of Cush.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The name of the third river is Tigris; it runs along the east side of Assyria. The fourth river is the Euphrates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God took the man and placed him in the orchard in Eden to care for it and to maintain it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord God commanded the man, “You may freely eat fruit from every tree of the orchard,
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: but you must not eat from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, for when you eat from it you will surely die.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The Lord God said, “It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make a companion for him who corresponds to him.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The Lord God formed out of the ground every living animal of the field and every bird of the air. He brought them to the man to see what he would name them, and whatever the man called each living creature, that was its name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the man named all the animals, the birds of the air, and the living creatures of the field, but for Adam no companion who corresponded to him was found.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord God caused the man to fall into a deep sleep, and while he was asleep, he took part of the man’s side and closed up the place with flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord God made a woman from the part he had taken out of the man, and he brought her to the man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the man said,
“This one at last is bone of my bones
and flesh of my flesh;
this one will be called ‘woman,’
for she was taken out of man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why a man leaves his father and mother and unites with his wife, and they become one family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man and his wife were both naked, but they were not ashamed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the serpent was shrewder than any of the wild animals that the Lord God had made. He said to the woman, “Is it really true that God said, ‘You must not eat from any tree of the orchard’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman said to the serpent, “We may eat of the fruit from the trees of the orchard;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but concerning the fruit of the tree that is in the middle of the orchard God said, ‘You must not eat from it, and you must not touch it, or else you will die.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The serpent said to the woman, “Surely you will not die,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for God knows that when you eat from it your eyes will open and you will be like God, knowing good and evil.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the woman saw that the tree produced fruit that was good for food, was attractive to the eye, and was desirable for making one wise, she took some of its fruit and ate it. She also gave some of it to her husband who was with her, and he ate it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the eyes of both of them opened, and they knew they were naked; so they sewed fig leaves together and made coverings for themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man and his wife heard the sound of the Lord God moving about in the orchard at the breezy time of the day, and they hid from the Lord God among the trees of the orchard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord God called to the man and said to him, “Where are you?”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The man replied, “I heard you moving about in the orchard, and I was afraid because I was naked, so I hid.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord God said, “Who told you that you were naked? Did you eat from the tree that I commanded you not to eat from?”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The man said, “The woman whom you gave me, she gave me some fruit from the tree and I ate it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord God said to the woman, “What is this you have done?” And the woman replied, “The serpent tricked me, and I ate.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
The Lord God said to the serpent,
“Because you have done this,
cursed are you above all the cattle
and all the living creatures of the field!
On your belly you will crawl
and dust you will eat all the days of your life.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
And I will put hostility between you and the woman
and between your offspring and her offspring;
he will strike your head,
and you will strike his heel.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
To the woman he said,
“I will greatly increase your labor pains;
with pain you will give birth to children.
You will want to control your husband,
but he will dominate you.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
But to Adam he said,
“Because you obeyed your wife
and ate from the tree about which I commanded you,
‘You must not eat from it,’
the ground is cursed because of you;
in painful toil you will eat of it all the days of your life.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
It will produce thorns and thistles for you,
but you will eat the grain of the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By the sweat of your brow you will eat food
until you return to the ground,
for out of it you were taken;
for you are dust, and to dust you will return.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The man named his wife Eve, because she was the mother of all the living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord God made garments from skin for Adam and his wife, and clothed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord God said, “Now that the man has become like one of us, knowing good and evil, he must not be allowed to stretch out his hand and take also from the tree of life and eat, and live forever.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So the Lord God expelled him from the orchard in Eden to cultivate the ground from which he had been taken.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: When he drove the man out, he placed on the eastern side of the orchard in Eden angelic sentries who used the flame of a whirling sword to guard the way to the tree of life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the man was intimate with his wife Eve, and she became pregnant and gave birth to Cain. Then she said, “I have created a man just as the Lord did!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she gave birth to his brother Abel. Abel took care of the flocks, while Cain cultivated the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the designated time Cain brought some of the fruit of the ground for an offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abel brought some of the firstborn of his flock—even the fattest of them. And the Lord was pleased with Abel and his offering,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but with Cain and his offering he was not pleased. So Cain became very angry, and his expression was downcast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Cain, “Why are you angry, and why is your expression downcast?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Is it not true that if you do what is right, you will be fine? But if you do not do what is right, sin is crouching at the door. It desires to dominate you, but you must subdue it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cain said to his brother Abel, “Let’s go out to the field.” While they were in the field, Cain attacked his brother Abel and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Cain, “Where is your brother Abel?” And he replied, “I don’t know! Am I my brother’s guardian?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord said, “What have you done? The voice of your brother’s blood is crying out to me from the ground!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now you are banished from the ground, which has opened its mouth to receive your brother’s blood from your hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you try to cultivate the ground it will no longer yield its best for you. You will be a homeless wanderer on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Cain said to the Lord, “My punishment is too great to endure!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, you are driving me off the land today, and I must hide from your presence. I will be a homeless wanderer on the earth; whoever finds me will kill me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord said to him, “All right then, if anyone kills Cain, Cain will be avenged seven times as much.” Then the Lord put a special mark on Cain so that no one who found him would strike him down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Cain went out from the presence of the Lord and lived in the land of Nod, east of Eden.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cain was intimate with his wife, and she became pregnant and gave birth to Enoch. Cain was building a city, and he named the city after his son Enoch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To Enoch was born Irad, and Irad was the father of Mehujael. Mehujael was the father of Methushael, and Methushael was the father of Lamech.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lamech took two wives for himself; the name of the first was Adah, and the name of the second was Zillah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adah gave birth to Jabal; he was the first of those who live in tents and keep livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The name of his brother was Jubal; he was the first of all who play the harp and the flute.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Zillah also gave birth to Tubal-Cain, who heated metal and shaped all kinds of tools made of bronze and iron. The sister of Tubal-Cain was Naamah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lamech said to his wives,
“Adah and Zillah, listen to me!
You wives of Lamech, hear my words!
I have killed a man for wounding me,
a young man for hurting me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If Cain is to be avenged seven times as much,
then Lamech seventy-seven times!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Adam was intimate with his wife again, and she gave birth to a son. She named him Seth, saying, “God has given me another child in place of Abel because Cain killed him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And a son was also born to Seth, whom he named Enosh. At that time people began to worship the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the record of the family line of Adam.
When God created humankind, he made them in the likeness of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He created them male and female; when they were created, he blessed them and named them “humankind.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Adam had lived 130 years he fathered a son in his own likeness, according to his image, and he named him Seth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The length of time Adam lived after he became the father of Seth was 800 years; during this time he had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire lifetime of Adam was 930 years, and then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Seth had lived 105 years, he became the father of Enosh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seth lived 807 years after he became the father of Enosh, and he had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire lifetime of Seth was 912 years, and then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Enosh had lived 90 years, he became the father of Kenan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Enosh lived 815 years after he became the father of Kenan, and he had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire lifetime of Enosh was 905 years, and then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Kenan had lived 70 years, he became the father of Mahalalel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kenan lived 840 years after he became the father of Mahalalel, and he had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire lifetime of Kenan was 910 years, and then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Mahalalel had lived 65 years, he became the father of Jared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mahalalel lived 830 years after he became the father of Jared, and he had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire lifetime of Mahalalel was 895 years, and then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jared had lived 162 years, he became the father of Enoch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jared lived 800 years after he became the father of Enoch, and he had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire lifetime of Jared was 962 years, and then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Enoch had lived 65 years, he became the father of Methuselah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he became the father of Methuselah, Enoch walked with God for 300 years, and he had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire lifetime of Enoch was 365 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Enoch walked with God, and then he disappeared because God took him away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Methuselah had lived 187 years, he became the father of Lamech.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Methuselah lived 782 years after he became the father of Lamech, and he had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire lifetime of Methuselah was 969 years, and then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Lamech had lived 182 years, he had a son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He named him Noah, saying, “This one will bring us comfort from our labor and from the painful toil of our hands because of the ground that the Lord has cursed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lamech lived 595 years after he became the father of Noah, and he had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire lifetime of Lamech was 777 years, and then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Noah was 500 years old, he became the father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When humankind began to multiply on the face of the earth, and daughters were born to them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the sons of God saw that the daughters of humankind were beautiful. Thus they took wives for themselves from any they chose.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord said, “My Spirit will not remain in humankind indefinitely, since they are mortal. They will remain for 120 more years.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Nephilim were on the earth in those days (and also after this) when the sons of God would sleep with the daughters of humankind, who gave birth to their children. They were the mighty heroes of old, the famous men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord saw that the wickedness of humankind had become great on the earth. Every inclination of the thoughts of their minds was only evil all the time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord regretted that he had made humankind on the earth, and he was highly offended.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord said, “I will wipe humankind, whom I have created, from the face of the earth—everything from humankind to animals, including creatures that move on the ground and birds of the air, for I regret that I have made them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Noah found favor in the sight of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account of Noah.
Noah was a godly man; he was blameless among his contemporaries. He walked with God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah had three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The earth was ruined in the sight of God; the earth was filled with violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God saw the earth, and indeed it was ruined, for all living creatures on the earth were sinful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God said to Noah, “I have decided that all living creatures must die, for the earth is filled with violence because of them. Now I am about to destroy them and the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make for yourself an ark of cypress wood. Make rooms in the ark, and cover it with pitch inside and out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is how you should make it: The ark is to be 450 feet long, 75 feet wide, and 45 feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make a roof for the ark and finish it, leaving 18 inches from the top. Put a door in the side of the ark, and make lower, middle, and upper decks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am about to bring floodwaters on the earth to destroy from under the sky all the living creatures that have the breath of life in them. Everything that is on the earth will die,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but I will confirm my covenant with you. You will enter the ark—you, your sons, your wife, and your sons’ wives with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must bring into the ark two of every kind of living creature from all flesh, male and female, to keep them alive with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Of the birds after their kinds, and of the cattle after their kinds, and of every creeping thing of the ground after its kind, two of every kind will come to you so you can keep them alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And you must take for yourself every kind of food that is eaten, and gather it together. It will be food for you and for them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Noah did all that God commanded him—he did indeed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Noah, “Come into the ark, you and all your household, for I consider you godly among this generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must take with you seven pairs of every kind of clean animal, the male and its mate, two of every kind of unclean animal, the male and its mate,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and also seven pairs of every kind of bird in the sky, male and female, to preserve their offspring on the face of the entire earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For in seven days I will cause it to rain on the earth for forty days and forty nights, and I will wipe from the face of the ground every living thing that I have made.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Noah did all that the Lord commanded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah was 600 years old when the floodwaters engulfed the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah entered the ark along with his sons, his wife, and his sons’ wives because of the floodwaters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pairs of clean animals, of unclean animals, of birds, and of everything that creeps along the ground,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: male and female, came into the ark to Noah, just as God had commanded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And after seven days the floodwaters engulfed the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the six hundredth year of Noah’s life, in the second month, on the seventeenth day of the month—on that day all the fountains of the great deep burst open and the floodgates of the heavens were opened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the rain fell on the earth forty days and forty nights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that very day Noah entered the ark, accompanied by his sons Shem, Ham, and Japheth, along with his wife and his sons’ three wives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They entered, along with every living creature after its kind, every animal after its kind, every creeping thing that creeps on the earth after its kind, and every bird after its kind, everything with wings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pairs of all creatures that have the breath of life came into the ark to Noah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those that entered were male and female, just as God commanded him. Then the Lord shut him in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The flood engulfed the earth for forty days. As the waters increased, they lifted the ark and raised it above the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The waters completely overwhelmed the earth, and the ark floated on the surface of the waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The waters completely inundated the earth so that even all the high mountains under the entire sky were covered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The waters rose more than 20 feet above the mountains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And all living things that moved on the earth died, including the birds, domestic animals, wild animals, all the creatures that swarm over the earth, and all humankind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything on dry land that had the breath of life in its nostrils died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord destroyed every living thing that was on the surface of the ground, including people, animals, creatures that creep along the ground, and birds of the sky. They were wiped off the earth. Only Noah and those who were with him in the ark survived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The waters prevailed over the earth for 150 days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God remembered Noah and all the wild animals and domestic animals that were with him in the ark. God caused a wind to blow over the earth and the waters receded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fountains of the deep and the floodgates of heaven were closed, and the rain stopped falling from the sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The waters kept receding steadily from the earth, so that they had gone down by the end of the 150 days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the seventeenth day of the seventh month, the ark came to rest on one of the mountains of Ararat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The waters kept on receding until the tenth month. On the first day of the tenth month, the tops of the mountains became visible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of forty days, Noah opened the window he had made in the ark
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and sent out a raven; it kept flying back and forth until the waters had dried up on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Noah sent out a dove to see if the waters had receded from the surface of the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The dove could not find a resting place for its feet because water still covered the surface of the entire earth, and so it returned to Noah in the ark. He stretched out his hand, took the dove, and brought it back into the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He waited seven more days and then sent out the dove again from the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the dove returned to him in the evening, there was a freshly plucked olive leaf in its beak! Noah knew that the waters had receded from the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He waited another seven days and sent the dove out again, but it did not return to him this time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Noah’s six hundred and first year, in the first day of the first month, the waters had dried up from the earth, and Noah removed the covering from the ark and saw that the surface of the ground was dry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And by the twenty-seventh day of the second month the earth was dry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God spoke to Noah and said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Come out of the ark, you, your wife, your sons, and your sons’ wives with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bring out with you all the living creatures that are with you. Bring out every living thing, including the birds, animals, and every creeping thing that creeps on the earth. Let them increase and be fruitful and multiply on the earth!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah went out along with his sons, his wife, and his sons’ wives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every living creature, every creeping thing, every bird, and everything that moves on the earth went out of the ark in their groups.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah built an altar to the Lord. He then took some of every kind of clean animal and clean bird and offered burnt offerings on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord smelled the soothing aroma and said to himself, “I will never again curse the ground because of humankind, even though the inclination of their minds is evil from childhood on. I will never again destroy everything that lives, as I have just done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“While the earth continues to exist,
planting time and harvest,
cold and heat,
summer and winter,
and day and night will not cease.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God blessed Noah and his sons and said to them, “Be fruitful and multiply and fill the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every living creature of the earth and every bird of the sky will be terrified of you. Everything that creeps on the ground and all the fish of the sea are under your authority.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You may eat any moving thing that lives. As I gave you the green plants, I now give you everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But you must not eat meat with its life (that is, its blood) in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For your lifeblood I will surely exact punishment, from every living creature I will exact punishment. From each person I will exact punishment for the life of the individual since the man was his relative.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Whoever sheds human blood,
by other humans
must his blood be shed;
for in God’s image
God has made humankind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But as for you, be fruitful and multiply; increase abundantly on the earth and multiply on it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to Noah and his sons,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look. I now confirm my covenant with you and your descendants after you
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and with every living creature that is with you, including the birds, the domestic animals, and every living creature of the earth with you, all those that came out of the ark with you—every living creature of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I confirm my covenant with you: Never again will all living things be wiped out by the waters of a flood; never again will a flood destroy the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And God said, “This is the guarantee of the covenant I am making with you and every living creature with you, a covenant for all subsequent generations:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will place my rainbow in the clouds, and it will become a guarantee of the covenant between me and the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever I bring clouds over the earth and the rainbow appears in the clouds,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I will remember my covenant with you and with all living creatures of all kinds. Never again will the waters become a flood and destroy all living things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the rainbow is in the clouds, I will notice it and remember the perpetual covenant between God and all living creatures of all kinds that are on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God said to Noah, “This is the guarantee of the covenant that I am confirming between me and all living things that are on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Noah who came out of the ark were Shem, Ham, and Japheth. (Now Ham was the father of Canaan.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the three sons of Noah, and from them the whole earth was populated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Noah, a man of the soil, began to plant a vineyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he drank some of the wine, he got drunk and uncovered himself inside his tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ham, the father of Canaan, saw his father’s nakedness and told his two brothers who were outside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shem and Japheth took the garment and placed it on their shoulders. Then they walked in backwards and covered up their father’s nakedness. Their faces were turned the other way so they did not see their father’s nakedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Noah awoke from his drunken stupor he learned what his youngest son had done to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So he said,
“Cursed be Canaan!
The lowest of slaves
he will be to his brothers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He also said,
“Worthy of praise is the Lord, the God of Shem!
May Canaan be the slave of Shem!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May God enlarge Japheth’s territory and numbers!
May he live in the tents of Shem
and may Canaan be the slave of Japheth!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the flood Noah lived 350 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire lifetime of Noah was 950 years, and then he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the account of Noah’s sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth. Sons were born to them after the flood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Japheth were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Gomer were Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Javan were Elishah, Tarshish, the Kittim, and the Dodanim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From these the coastlands of the nations were separated into their lands, every one according to its language, according to their families, by their nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Ham were Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Cush were Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabteca. The sons of Raamah were Sheba and Dedan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cush was the father of Nimrod; he began to be a valiant warrior on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was a mighty hunter before the Lord. (That is why it is said, “Like Nimrod, a mighty hunter before the Lord.”)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The primary regions of his kingdom were Babel, Erech, Akkad, and Calneh in the land of Shinar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From that land he went to Assyria, where he built Nineveh, Rehoboth Ir, Calah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Resen, which is between Nineveh and the great city Calah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mizraim was the father of the Ludites, Anamites, Lehabites, Naphtuhites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pathrusites, Casluhites (from whom the Philistines came), and Caphtorites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Canaan was the father of Sidon his firstborn, Heth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Jebusites, Amorites, Girgashites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hivites, Arkites, Sinites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Arvadites, Zemarites, and Hamathites. Eventually the families of the Canaanites were scattered
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the borders of Canaan extended from Sidon all the way to Gerar as far as Gaza, and all the way to Sodom, Gomorrah, Admah, and Zeboyim, as far as Lasha.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the sons of Ham, according to their families, according to their languages, by their lands, and by their nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And sons were also born to Shem (the older brother of Japheth), the father of all the sons of Eber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Shem were Elam, Asshur, Arphaxad, Lud, and Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Aram were Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Arphaxad was the father of Shelah, and Shelah was the father of Eber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two sons were born to Eber: One was named Peleg because in his days the earth was divided, and his brother’s name was Joktan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joktan was the father of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Obal, Abimael, Sheba,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were sons of Joktan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their dwelling place was from Mesha all the way to Sephar in the eastern hills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the sons of Shem according to their families, according to their languages, by their lands, and according to their nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the families of the sons of Noah, according to their genealogies, by their nations, and from these the nations spread over the earth after the flood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole earth had a common language and a common vocabulary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people moved eastward, they found a plain in Shinar and settled there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said to one another, “Come, let’s make bricks and bake them thoroughly.” (They had brick instead of stone and tar instead of mortar.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said, “Come, let’s build ourselves a city and a tower with its top in the heavens so that we may make a name for ourselves. Otherwise we will be scattered across the face of the entire earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord came down to see the city and the tower that the people had started building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And the Lord said, “If as one people all sharing a common language they have begun to do this, then nothing they plan to do will be beyond them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come, let’s go down and confuse their language so they won’t be able to understand each other.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord scattered them from there across the face of the entire earth, and they stopped building the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why its name was called Babel—because there the Lord confused the language of the entire world, and from there the Lord scattered them across the face of the entire earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account of Shem.
Shem was 100 years old when he became the father of Arphaxad, two years after the flood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And after becoming the father of Arphaxad, Shem lived 500 years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Arphaxad had lived 35 years, he became the father of Shelah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And after he became the father of Shelah, Arphaxad lived 403 years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Shelah had lived 30 years, he became the father of Eber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And after he became the father of Eber, Shelah lived 403 years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Eber had lived 34 years, he became the father of Peleg.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And after he became the father of Peleg, Eber lived 430 years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Peleg had lived 30 years, he became the father of Reu.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And after he became the father of Reu, Peleg lived 209 years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Reu had lived 32 years, he became the father of Serug.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And after he became the father of Serug, Reu lived 207 years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Serug had lived 30 years, he became the father of Nahor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And after he became the father of Nahor, Serug lived 200 years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Nahor had lived 29 years, he became the father of Terah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And after he became the father of Terah, Nahor lived 119 years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Terah had lived 70 years, he became the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account of Terah.
Terah became the father of Abram, Nahor, and Haran. And Haran became the father of Lot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Haran died in the land of his birth, in Ur of the Chaldeans, while his father Terah was still alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Abram and Nahor took wives for themselves. The name of Abram’s wife was Sarai. And the name of Nahor’s wife was Milcah; she was the daughter of Haran, who was the father of both Milcah and Iscah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Sarai was barren; she had no children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Terah took his son Abram, his grandson Lot (the son of Haran), and his daughter-in-law Sarai, his son Abram’s wife, and with them he set out from Ur of the Chaldeans to go to Canaan. When they came to Haran, they settled there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The lifetime of Terah was 205 years, and he died in Haran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now the Lord said to Abram,
“Go out from your country, your relatives, and your father’s household
to the land that I will show you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I will make you into a great nation, and I will bless you,
and I will make your name great,
so that you will exemplify divine blessing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will bless those who bless you,
but the one who treats you lightly I must curse,
so that all the families of the earth may receive blessing through you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abram left, just as the Lord had told him to do, and Lot went with him. (Now Abram was 75 years old when he departed from Haran.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Abram took his wife Sarai, his nephew Lot, and all the possessions they had accumulated and the people they had acquired in Haran, and they left for the land of Canaan. They entered the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram traveled through the land as far as the oak tree of Moreh at Shechem. (At that time the Canaanites were in the land.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord appeared to Abram and said, “To your descendants I will give this land.” So Abram built an altar there to the Lord, who had appeared to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he moved from there to the hill country east of Bethel and pitched his tent, with Bethel on the west and Ai on the east. There he built an altar to the Lord and worshiped the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram continually journeyed by stages down to the Negev.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a famine in the land, so Abram went down to Egypt to stay for a while because the famine was severe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he approached Egypt, he said to his wife Sarai, “Look, I know that you are a beautiful woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Egyptians see you they will say, ‘This is his wife.’ Then they will kill me but will keep you alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So tell them you are my sister so that it may go well for me because of you and my life will be spared on account of you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abram entered Egypt, the Egyptians saw that the woman was very beautiful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh’s officials saw her, they praised her to Pharaoh. So Abram’s wife was taken into the household of Pharaoh,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he did treat Abram well on account of her. Abram received sheep and cattle, male donkeys, male servants, female servants, female donkeys, and camels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord struck Pharaoh and his household with severe diseases because of Sarai, Abram’s wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Pharaoh summoned Abram and said, “What is this you have done to me? Why didn’t you tell me that she was your wife?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why did you say, ‘She is my sister,’ so that I took her to be my wife? Now, here is your wife. Take her and go!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh gave his men orders about Abram, and so they expelled him, along with his wife and all his possessions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abram went up from Egypt into the Negev. He took his wife and all his possessions with him, as well as Lot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now Abram was very wealthy in livestock, silver, and gold.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he journeyed from place to place from the Negev as far as Bethel. He returned to the place where he had pitched his tent at the beginning, between Bethel and Ai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was the place where he had first built the altar, and there Abram worshiped the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Lot, who was traveling with Abram, also had flocks, herds, and tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the land could not support them while they were living side by side. Because their possessions were so great, they were not able to live alongside one another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So there were quarrels between Abram’s herdsmen and Lot’s herdsmen. (Now the Canaanites and the Perizzites were living in the land at that time.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram said to Lot, “Let there be no quarreling between me and you, and between my herdsmen and your herdsmen, for we are close relatives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Is not the whole land before you? Separate yourself now from me. If you go to the left, then I’ll go to the right, but if you go to the right, then I’ll go to the left.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lot looked up and saw the whole region of the Jordan. He noticed that all of it was well watered (this was before the Lord obliterated Sodom and Gomorrah) like the garden of the Lord, like the land of Egypt, all the way to Zoar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lot chose for himself the whole region of the Jordan and traveled toward the east.
So the relatives separated from each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram settled in the land of Canaan, but Lot settled among the cities of the Jordan plain and pitched his tents next to Sodom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now the people of Sodom were extremely wicked rebels against the Lord.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Lot had departed, the Lord said to Abram, “Look from the place where you stand to the north, south, east, and west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give all the land that you see to you and your descendants forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I will make your descendants like the dust of the earth, so that if anyone is able to count the dust of the earth, then your descendants also can be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Get up and walk throughout the land, for I will give it to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abram moved his tents and went to live by the oaks of Mamre in Hebron, and he built an altar to the Lord there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Amraphel king of Shinar, Arioch king of Ellasar, Kedorlaomer king of Elam, and Tidal king of nations
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: went to war against Bera king of Sodom, Birsha king of Gomorrah, Shinab king of Admah, Shemeber king of Zeboyim, and the king of Bela (that is, Zoar).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These last five kings joined forces in the Valley of Siddim (that is, the Salt Sea).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For twelve years they had served Kedorlaomer, but in the thirteenth year they rebelled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fourteenth year, Kedorlaomer and the kings who were his allies came and defeated the Rephaites in Ashteroth Karnaim, the Zuzites in Ham, the Emites in Shaveh Kiriathaim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Horites in their hill country of Seir, as far as El Paran, which is near the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they attacked En Mishpat (that is, Kadesh) again, and they conquered all the territory of the Amalekites, as well as the Amorites who were living in Hazezon Tamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Sodom, the king of Gomorrah, the king of Admah, the king of Zeboyim, and the king of Bela (that is, Zoar) went out and prepared for battle. In the Valley of Siddim they met
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kedorlaomer king of Elam, Tidal king of nations, Amraphel king of Shinar, and Arioch king of Ellasar. Four kings fought against five.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Valley of Siddim was full of tar pits. When the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled, they fell into them, but some survivors fled to the hills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The four victorious kings took all the possessions and food of Sodom and Gomorrah and left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also took Abram’s nephew Lot and his possessions when they left, for Lot was living in Sodom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A fugitive came and told Abram the Hebrew. Now Abram was living by the oaks of Mamre the Amorite, the brother of Eshcol and Aner. (All these were allied by treaty with Abram.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abram heard that his nephew had been taken captive, he mobilized his 318 trained men who had been born in his household, and he pursued the invaders as far as Dan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then, during the night, Abram divided his forces against them and defeated them. He chased them as far as Hobah, which is north of Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He retrieved all the stolen property. He also brought back his nephew Lot and his possessions, as well as the women and the rest of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Abram returned from defeating Kedorlaomer and the kings who were with him, the king of Sodom went out to meet Abram in the Valley of Shaveh (known as the King’s Valley).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Melchizedek king of Salem brought out bread and wine. (Now he was the priest of the Most High God.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He blessed Abram, saying,
“Blessed be Abram by the Most High God,
Creator of heaven and earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Worthy of praise is the Most High God,
who delivered your enemies into your hand.” 
Abram gave Melchizedek a tenth of everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Sodom said to Abram, “Give me the people and take the possessions for yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abram replied to the king of Sodom, “I raise my hand to the Lord, the Most High God, Creator of heaven and earth, and vow
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that I will take nothing belonging to you, not even a thread or the strap of a sandal. That way you can never say, ‘It is I who made Abram rich.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will take nothing except compensation for what the young men have eaten. As for the share of the men who went with me—Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre—let them take their share.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After these things the Lord’s message came to Abram in a vision: “Fear not, Abram! I am your shield and the one who will reward you in great abundance.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abram said, “O Sovereign Lord, what will you give me since I continue to be childless, and my heir is Eliezer of Damascus?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram added, “Since you have not given me a descendant, then look, one born in my house will be my heir!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But look, the Lord’s message came to him: “This man will not be your heir, but instead a son who comes from your own body will be your heir.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord took him outside and said, “Gaze into the sky and count the stars—if you are able to count them!” Then he said to him, “So will your descendants be.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram believed the Lord, and the Lord credited it as righteousness to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to him, “I am the Lord who brought you out from Ur of the Chaldeans to give you this land to possess.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abram said, “O Sovereign Lord, by what can I know that I am to possess it?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to him, “Take for me a heifer, a goat, and a ram, each three years old, along with a dove and a young pigeon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abram took all these for him and then cut them in two and placed each half opposite the other, but he did not cut the birds in half.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When birds of prey came down on the carcasses, Abram drove them away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sun went down, Abram fell sound asleep, and great terror overwhelmed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Abram, “Know for certain that your descendants will be strangers in a foreign country. They will be enslaved and oppressed for 400 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will execute judgment on the nation that they will serve. Afterward they will come out with many possessions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as for you, you will go to your ancestors in peace and be buried at a good old age.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fourth generation your descendants will return here, for the sin of the Amorites has not yet reached its limit.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sun had gone down and it was dark, a smoking firepot with a flaming torch passed between the animal parts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day the Lord made a covenant with Abram: “To your descendants I give this land, from the river of Egypt to the great river, the Euphrates River—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the land of the Kenites, Kenizzites, Kadmonites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hittites, Perizzites, Rephaites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amorites, Canaanites, Girgashites, and Jebusites.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Sarai, Abram’s wife, had not given birth to any children, but she had an Egyptian servant named Hagar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Sarai said to Abram, “Since the Lord has prevented me from having children, please sleep with my servant. Perhaps I can have a family by her.” Abram did what Sarai told him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So after Abram had lived in Canaan for ten years, Sarai, Abram’s wife, gave Hagar, her Egyptian servant, to her husband to be his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He slept with Hagar, and she became pregnant. Once Hagar realized she was pregnant, she despised Sarai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Sarai said to Abram, “You have brought this wrong on me! I gave my servant into your embrace, but when she realized that she was pregnant, she despised me. May the Lord judge between you and me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram said to Sarai, “Since your servant is under your authority, do to her whatever you think best.” Then Sarai treated Hagar harshly, so she ran away from Sarai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The angel of the Lord found Hagar near a spring of water in the wilderness—the spring that is along the road to Shur.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Hagar, servant of Sarai, where have you come from, and where are you going?” She replied, “I’m running away from my mistress, Sarai.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the angel of the Lord said to her, “Return to your mistress and submit to her authority.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will greatly multiply your descendants,” the angel of the Lord added, “so that they will be too numerous to count.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the angel of the Lord said to her,
“You are now pregnant
and are about to give birth to a son.
You are to name him Ishmael,
for the Lord has heard your painful groans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will be a wild donkey of a man.
He will be hostile to everyone,
and everyone will be hostile to him.
He will live away from his brothers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hagar named the Lord who spoke to her, “You are the God who sees me,” for she said, “Here I have seen one who sees me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why the well was called Beer Lahai Roi. (It is located between Kadesh and Bered.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hagar gave birth to Abram’s son, whom Abram named Ishmael.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now Abram was 86 years old when Hagar gave birth to Ishmael.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abram was 99 years old, the Lord appeared to him and said, “I am the Sovereign God. Walk before me and be blameless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will confirm my covenant between me and you, and I will give you a multitude of descendants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abram bowed down with his face to the ground, and God said to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for me, this is my covenant with you: You will be the father of a multitude of nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No longer will your name be Abram. Instead, your name will be Abraham because I will make you the father of a multitude of nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make you extremely fruitful. I will make nations of you, and kings will descend from you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will confirm my covenant as a perpetual covenant between me and you. It will extend to your descendants after you throughout their generations. I will be your God and the God of your descendants after you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give the whole land of Canaan—the land where you are now residing—to you and your descendants after you as a permanent possession. I will be their God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God said to Abraham, “As for you, you must keep the covenantal requirement I am imposing on you and your descendants after you throughout their generations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is my requirement that you and your descendants after you must keep: Every male among you must be circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must circumcise the flesh of your foreskins. This will be a reminder of the covenant between me and you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Throughout your generations every male among you who is eight days old must be circumcised, whether born in your house or bought with money from any foreigner who is not one of your descendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They must indeed be circumcised, whether born in your house or bought with money. The sign of my covenant will be visible in your flesh as a permanent reminder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Any uncircumcised male who has not been circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin will be cut off from his people—he has failed to carry out my requirement.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God said to Abraham, “As for your wife, you must no longer call her Sarai; Sarah will be her name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bless her and will give you a son through her. I will bless her and she will become a mother of nations. Kings of countries will come from her!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham bowed down with his face to the ground and laughed as he said to himself, “Can a son be born to a man who is a hundred years old? Can Sarah bear a child at the age of ninety?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham said to God, “O that Ishmael might live before you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “No, Sarah your wife is going to bear you a son, and you will name him Isaac. I will confirm my covenant with him as a perpetual covenant for his descendants after him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for Ishmael, I have heard you. I will indeed bless him, make him fruitful, and give him a multitude of descendants. He will become the father of twelve princes; I will make him into a great nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will establish my covenant with Isaac, whom Sarah will bear to you at this set time next year.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he finished speaking with Abraham, God went up from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham took his son Ishmael and every male in his household (whether born in his house or bought with money) and circumcised them on that very same day, just as God had told him to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Abraham was 99 years old when he was circumcised;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: his son Ishmael was thirteen years old when he was circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham and his son Ishmael were circumcised on the very same day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the men of his household, whether born in his household or bought with money from a foreigner, were circumcised with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord appeared to Abraham by the oaks of Mamre while he was sitting at the entrance to his tent during the hottest time of the day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham looked up and saw three men standing across from him. When he saw them he ran from the entrance of the tent to meet them and bowed low to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “My lord, if I have found favor in your sight, do not pass by and leave your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let a little water be brought so that you may all wash your feet and rest under the tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And let me get a bit of food so that you may refresh yourselves since you have passed by your servant’s home. After that you may be on your way.” “All right,” they replied, “you may do as you say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abraham hurried into the tent and said to Sarah, “Quick! Take three measures of fine flour, knead it, and make bread.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham ran to the herd and chose a fine, tender calf, and gave it to a servant, who quickly prepared it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham then took some curds and milk, along with the calf that had been prepared, and placed the food before them. They ate while he was standing near them under a tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they asked him, “Where is Sarah your wife?” He replied, “There, in the tent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of them said, “I will surely return to you when the season comes round again, and your wife Sarah will have a son!” (Now Sarah was listening at the entrance to the tent, not far behind him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham and Sarah were old and advancing in years; Sarah had long since passed menopause.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Sarah laughed to herself, thinking, “After I am worn out will I have pleasure, especially when my husband is old too?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Abraham, “Why did Sarah laugh and say, ‘Will I really have a child when I am old?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Is anything impossible for the Lord? I will return to you when the season comes round again and Sarah will have a son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Sarah lied, saying, “I did not laugh,” because she was afraid. But the Lord said, “No! You did laugh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the men got up to leave, they looked out over Sodom. (Now Abraham was walking with them to see them on their way.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said, “Should I hide from Abraham what I am about to do?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all, Abraham will surely become a great and powerful nation, and all the nations on the earth may receive blessing through him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have chosen him so that he may command his children and his household after him to keep the way of the Lord by doing what is right and just. Then the Lord will give to Abraham what he promised him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord said, “The outcry against Sodom and Gomorrah is so great and their sin so blatant
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: that I must go down and see if they are as wicked as the outcry suggests. If not, I want to know.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two men turned and headed toward Sodom, but Abraham was still standing before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham approached and said, “Will you really sweep away the godly along with the wicked?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What if there are fifty godly people in the city? Will you really wipe it out and not spare the place for the sake of the fifty godly people who are in it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Far be it from you to do such a thing—to kill the godly with the wicked, treating the godly and the wicked alike! Far be it from you! Will not the judge of the whole earth do what is right?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord replied, “If I find in the city of Sodom fifty godly people, I will spare the whole place for their sake.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham asked, “Since I have undertaken to speak to the Lord (although I am but dust and ashes),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: what if there are five less than the fifty godly people? Will you destroy the whole city because five are lacking?” He replied, “I will not destroy it if I find forty-five there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham spoke to him again, “What if forty are found there?” He replied, “I will not do it for the sake of the forty.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham said, “May the Lord not be angry so that I may speak! What if thirty are found there?” He replied, “I will not do it if I find thirty there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham said, “Since I have undertaken to speak to the Lord, what if only twenty are found there?” He replied, “I will not destroy it for the sake of the twenty.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Finally Abraham said, “May the Lord not be angry so that I may speak just once more. What if ten are found there?” He replied, “I will not destroy it for the sake of the ten.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord went on his way when he had finished speaking to Abraham. Then Abraham returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two angels came to Sodom in the evening while Lot was sitting in the city’s gateway. When Lot saw them, he got up to meet them and bowed down with his face toward the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Here, my lords, please turn aside to your servant’s house. Stay the night and wash your feet. Then you can be on your way early in the morning.” “No,” they replied, “we’ll spend the night in the town square.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he urged them persistently, so they turned aside with him and entered his house. He prepared a feast for them, including bread baked without yeast, and they ate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Before they could lie down to sleep, all the men—both young and old, from every part of the city of Sodom—surrounded the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They shouted to Lot, “Where are the men who came to you tonight? Bring them out to us so we can take carnal knowledge of them!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lot went outside to them, shutting the door behind him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “No, my brothers! Don’t act so wickedly!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, I have two daughters who have never been intimate with a man. Let me bring them out to you, and you can do to them whatever you please. Only don’t do anything to these men, for they have come under the protection of my roof.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Out of our way!” they cried, “This man came to live here as a foreigner, and now he dares to judge us! We’ll do more harm to you than to them!” They kept pressing in on Lot until they were close enough to break down the door.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men inside reached out and pulled Lot back into the house as they shut the door.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they struck the men who were at the door of the house, from the youngest to the oldest, with blindness. The men outside wore themselves out trying to find the door.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the two visitors said to Lot, “Who else do you have here? Do you have any sons-in-law, sons, daughters, or other relatives in the city? Get them out of this place
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because we are about to destroy it. The outcry against this place is so great before the Lord that he has sent us to destroy it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Lot went out and spoke to his sons-in-law who were going to marry his daughters. He said, “Quick, get out of this place because the Lord is about to destroy the city!” But his sons-in-law thought he was ridiculing them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At dawn the angels hurried Lot along, saying, “Get going! Take your wife and your two daughters who are here, or else you will be destroyed when the city is judged!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Lot hesitated, the men grabbed his hand and the hands of his wife and two daughters because the Lord had compassion on them. They led them away and placed them outside the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had brought them outside, they said, “Run for your lives! Don’t look behind you or stop anywhere in the valley! Escape to the mountains or you will be destroyed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Lot said to them, “No, please, Lord!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant has found favor with you, and you have shown me great kindness by sparing my life. But I am not able to escape to the mountains because this disaster will overtake me and I’ll die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, this town over here is close enough to escape to, and it’s just a little one. Let me go there. It’s just a little place, isn’t it? Then I’ll survive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Very well,” he replied, “I will grant this request too and will not overthrow the town you mentioned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Run there quickly, for I cannot do anything until you arrive there.” (This incident explains why the town was called Zoar.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sun had just risen over the land as Lot reached Zoar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord rained down sulfur and fire on Sodom and Gomorrah. It was sent down from the sky by the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he overthrew those cities and all that region, including all the inhabitants of the cities and the vegetation that grew from the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Lot’s wife looked back longingly and was turned into a pillar of salt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham got up early in the morning and went to the place where he had stood before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He looked out toward Sodom and Gomorrah and all the land of that region. As he did so, he saw the smoke rising up from the land like smoke from a furnace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when God destroyed the cities of the region, God honored Abraham’s request. He removed Lot from the midst of the destruction when he destroyed the cities Lot had lived in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Lot went up from Zoar with his two daughters and settled in the mountains because he was afraid to live in Zoar. So he lived in a cave with his two daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later the older daughter said to the younger, “Our father is old, and there is no man in the country to sleep with us, the way everyone does.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come, let’s make our father drunk with wine so we can go to bed with him and preserve our family line through our father.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So that night they made their father drunk with wine, and the older daughter came in and went to bed with her father. But he was not aware of when she lay down with him or when she got up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So in the morning the older daughter said to the younger, “Since I went to bed with my father last night, let’s make him drunk again tonight. Then you go in and go to bed with him so we can preserve our family line through our father.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they made their father drunk that night as well, and the younger one came and went to bed with him. But he was not aware of when she lay down with him or when she got up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way both of Lot’s daughters became pregnant by their father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The older daughter gave birth to a son and named him Moab. He is the ancestor of the Moabites of today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The younger daughter also gave birth to a son and named him Ben Ammi. He is the ancestor of the Ammonites of today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham journeyed from there to the Negev region and settled between Kadesh and Shur. While he lived as a temporary resident in Gerar,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham said about his wife Sarah, “She is my sister.” So Abimelech, king of Gerar, sent for Sarah and took her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God appeared to Abimelech in a dream at night and said to him, “You are as good as dead because of the woman you have taken, for she is someone else’s wife.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Abimelech had not gone near her. He said, “Lord, would you really slaughter an innocent nation?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Did Abraham not say to me, ‘She is my sister’? And she herself said, ‘He is my brother.’ I have done this with a clear conscience and with innocent hands!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then in the dream God replied to him, “Yes, I know that you have done this with a clear conscience. That is why I have kept you from sinning against me and why I did not allow you to touch her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now give back the man’s wife. Indeed he is a prophet and he will pray for you; thus you will live. But if you don’t give her back, know that you will surely die along with all who belong to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early in the morning Abimelech summoned all his servants. When he told them about all these things, they were terrified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelech summoned Abraham and said to him, “What have you done to us? What sin did I commit against you that would cause you to bring such great guilt on me and my kingdom? You have done things to me that should not be done!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abimelech asked Abraham, “What prompted you to do this thing?”
verses.speaker: Narrator
