verses.text: Abraham replied, “Because I thought, ‘Surely no one fears God in this place. They will kill me because of my wife.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What’s more, she is indeed my sister, my father’s daughter, but not my mother’s daughter. She became my wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When God made me wander from my father’s house, I told her, ‘This is what you can do to show your loyalty to me: Every place we go, say about me, “He is my brother.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abimelech gave sheep, cattle, and male and female servants to Abraham. He also gave his wife Sarah back to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abimelech said, “Look, my land is before you; live wherever you please.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To Sarah he said, “Look, I have given 1,000 pieces of silver to your ‘brother.’ This is compensation for you so that you will stand vindicated before all who are with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham prayed to God, and God healed Abimelech, as well as his wife and female slaves so that they were able to have children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the Lord had caused infertility to strike every woman in the household of Abimelech because he took Sarah, Abraham’s wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord visited Sarah just as he had said he would and did for Sarah what he had promised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Sarah became pregnant and bore Abraham a son in his old age at the appointed time that God had told him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham named his son—whom Sarah bore to him—Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his son Isaac was eight days old, Abraham circumcised him just as God had commanded him to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now Abraham was 100 years old when his son Isaac was born to him.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarah said, “God has made me laugh. Everyone who hears about this will laugh with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She went on to say, “Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet I have given birth to a son for him in his old age!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The child grew and was weaned. Abraham prepared a great feast on the day that Isaac was weaned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Sarah noticed the son of Hagar the Egyptian—the son whom Hagar had borne to Abraham—mocking.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she said to Abraham, “Banish that slave woman and her son, for the son of that slave woman will not be an heir along with my son Isaac!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarah’s demand displeased Abraham greatly because Ishmael was his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God said to Abraham, “Do not be upset about the boy or your slave wife. Do all that Sarah is telling you because through Isaac your descendants will be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will also make the son of the slave wife into a great nation, for he is your descendant too.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early in the morning Abraham took some food and a skin of water and gave them to Hagar. He put them on her shoulders, gave her the child, and sent her away. So she went wandering aimlessly through the wilderness of Beer Sheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the water in the skin was gone, she shoved the child under one of the shrubs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she went and sat down by herself across from him at quite a distance, about a bowshot, away; for she thought, “I refuse to watch the child die.” So she sat across from him and wept uncontrollably.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God heard the boy’s voice. The angel of God called to Hagar from heaven and asked her, “What is the matter, Hagar? Don’t be afraid, for God has heard the boy’s voice right where he is crying.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Get up! Help the boy up and hold him by the hand, for I will make him into a great nation.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God enabled Hagar to see a well of water. She went over and filled the skin with water, and then gave the boy a drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God was with the boy as he grew. He lived in the wilderness and became an archer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He lived in the wilderness of Paran. His mother found a wife for him from the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, said to Abraham, “God is with you in all that you do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now swear to me right here in God’s name that you will not deceive me, my children, or my descendants. Show me, and the land where you are staying, the same loyalty that I have shown you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham said, “I swear to do this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abraham lodged a complaint against Abimelech concerning a well that Abimelech’s servants had seized.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I do not know who has done this thing,” Abimelech replied. “Moreover, you did not tell me. I did not hear about it until today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham took some sheep and cattle and gave them to Abimelech. The two of them made a treaty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham set seven ewe lambs apart from the flock by themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abimelech asked Abraham, “What is the meaning of these seven ewe lambs that you have set apart?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He replied, “You must take these seven ewe lambs from my hand as legal proof that I dug this well.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why he named that place Beer Sheba, because the two of them swore an oath there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they made a treaty at Beer Sheba; then Abimelech and Phicol, the commander of his army, returned to the land of the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham planted a tamarisk tree in Beer Sheba. There he worshiped the Lord, the eternal God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abraham stayed in the land of the Philistines for quite some time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time after these things God tested Abraham. He said to him, “Abraham!” “Here I am!” Abraham replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said, “Take your son—your only son, whom you love, Isaac—and go to the land of Moriah! Offer him up there as a burnt offering on one of the mountains which I will indicate to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early in the morning Abraham got up and saddled his donkey. He took two of his young servants with him, along with his son Isaac. When he had cut the wood for the burnt offering, he started out for the place God had spoken to him about.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day Abraham caught sight of the place in the distance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he said to his servants, “You two stay here with the donkey while the boy and I go up there. We will worship and then return to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham took the wood for the burnt offering and put it on his son Isaac. Then he took the fire and the knife in his hand, and the two of them walked on together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac said to his father Abraham, “My father?” “What is it, my son?” he replied. “Here is the fire and the wood,” Isaac said, “but where is the lamb for the burnt offering?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “God will provide for himself the lamb for the burnt offering, my son,” Abraham replied. The two of them continued on together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to the place God had told him about, Abraham built the altar there and arranged the wood on it. Next he tied up his son Isaac and placed him on the altar on top of the wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham reached out his hand, took the knife, and prepared to slaughter his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the angel of the Lord called to him from heaven, “Abraham! Abraham!” “Here I am!” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not harm the boy!” the angel said. “Do not do anything to him, for now I know that you fear God because you did not withhold your son, your only son, from me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham looked up and saw behind him a ram caught in the bushes by its horns. So he went over and got the ram and offered it up as a burnt offering instead of his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Abraham called the name of that place “The Lord provides.” It is said to this day, “In the mountain of the Lord provision will be made.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The angel of the Lord called to Abraham a second time from heaven
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said, “I solemnly swear by my own name, decrees the Lord, that because you have done this and have not withheld your son, your only son,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will indeed bless you, and I will greatly multiply your descendants so that they will be as countless as the stars in the sky or the grains of sand on the seashore. Your descendants will take possession of the strongholds of their enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because you have obeyed me, all the nations of the earth will pronounce blessings on one another using the name of your descendants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham returned to his servants, and they set out together for Beer Sheba where Abraham stayed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After these things Abraham was told, “Milcah also has borne children to your brother Nahor—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uz the firstborn, his brother Buz, Kemuel (the father of Aram),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kesed, Hazo, Pildash, Jidlaph, and Bethuel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now Bethuel became the father of Rebekah.) These were the eight sons Milcah bore to Abraham’s brother Nahor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His concubine, whose name was Reumah, also bore him children—Tebah, Gaham, Tahash, and Maacah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sarah lived 127 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she died in Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron) in the land of Canaan. Abraham went to mourn for Sarah and to weep for her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham got up from mourning his dead wife and said to the sons of Heth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am a foreign resident, a temporary settler, among you. Grant me ownership of a burial site among you so that I may bury my dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Heth answered Abraham,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Listen, sir, you are a mighty prince among us! You may bury your dead in the choicest of our tombs. None of us will refuse you his tomb to prevent you from burying your dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham got up and bowed down to the local people, the sons of Heth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to them, “If you agree that I may bury my dead, then hear me out. Ask Ephron the son of Zohar
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: if he will sell me the cave of Machpelah that belongs to him; it is at the end of his field. Let him sell it to me publicly for the full price, so that I may own it as a burial site.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now Ephron was sitting among the sons of Heth.) Ephron the Hittite replied to Abraham in the hearing of the sons of Heth—before all who entered the gate of his city—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No, my lord! Hear me out. I sell you both the field and the cave that is in it. In the presence of my people I sell it to you. Bury your dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham bowed before the local people
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said to Ephron in their hearing, “Hear me, if you will. I pay to you the price of the field. Take it from me so that I may bury my dead there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ephron answered Abraham, saying to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Hear me, my lord. The land is worth 400 pieces of silver, but what is that between me and you? So bury your dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abraham agreed to Ephron’s price and weighed out for him the price that Ephron had quoted in the hearing of the sons of Heth—400 pieces of silver, according to the standard measurement at the time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abraham secured Ephron’s field in Machpelah, next to Mamre, including the field, the cave that was in it, and all the trees that were in the field and all around its border,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: as his property in the presence of the sons of Heth before all who entered the gate of Ephron’s city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the cave in the field of Machpelah next to Mamre (that is, Hebron) in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abraham secured the field and the cave that was in it as a burial site from the sons of Heth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Abraham was old, well advanced in years, and the Lord had blessed him in everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham said to his servant, the senior one in his household who was in charge of everything he had, “Put your hand under my thigh
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so that I may make you solemnly promise by the Lord, the God of heaven and the God of the earth: You must not acquire a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I am living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must go instead to my country and to my relatives to find a wife for my son Isaac.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant asked him, “What if the woman is not willing to come back with me to this land? Must I then take your son back to the land from which you came?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Be careful never to take my son back there!” Abraham told him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord, the God of heaven, who took me from my father’s house and the land of my relatives, promised me with a solemn oath, ‘To your descendants I will give this land.’ He will send his angel before you so that you may find a wife for my son from there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the woman is not willing to come back with you, you will be free from this oath of mine. But you must not take my son back there!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the servant placed his hand under the thigh of his master Abraham and gave his solemn promise he would carry out his wishes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the servant took ten of his master’s camels and departed with all kinds of gifts from his master at his disposal. He journeyed to the region of Aram Naharaim and the city of Nahor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the camels kneel down by the well outside the city. It was evening, the time when the women would go out to draw water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He prayed, “O Lord, God of my master Abraham, guide me today. Be faithful to my master Abraham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here I am, standing by the spring, and the daughters of the people who live in the town are coming out to draw water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will say to a young woman, ‘Please lower your jar so I may drink.’ May the one you have chosen for your servant Isaac reply, ‘Drink, and I’ll give your camels water too.’ In this way I will know that you have been faithful to my master.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Before he had finished praying, there came Rebekah with her water jug on her shoulder. She was the daughter of Bethuel son of Milcah (Milcah was the wife of Abraham’s brother Nahor).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the young woman was very beautiful. She was a virgin; no man had ever been physically intimate with her. She went down to the spring, filled her jug, and came back up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham’s servant ran to meet her and said, “Please give me a sip of water from your jug.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Drink, my lord,” she replied, and quickly lowering her jug to her hands, she gave him a drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she had done so, she said, “I’ll draw water for your camels too, until they have drunk as much as they want.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She quickly emptied her jug into the watering trough and ran back to the well to draw more water until she had drawn enough for all his camels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Silently the man watched her with interest to determine if the Lord had made his journey successful or not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the camels had finished drinking, the man took out a gold nose ring weighing a beka and two gold wrist bracelets weighing ten shekels and gave them to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Whose daughter are you?” he asked. “Tell me, is there room in your father’s house for us to spend the night?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said to him, “I am the daughter of Bethuel the son of Milcah, whom Milcah bore to Nahor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have plenty of straw and feed,” she added, “and room for you to spend the night.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man bowed his head and worshiped the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: saying, “Praised be the Lord, the God of my master Abraham, who has not abandoned his faithful love for my master! The Lord has led me to the house of my master’s relatives!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young woman ran and told her mother’s household all about these things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now Rebekah had a brother named Laban.) Laban rushed out to meet the man at the spring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he saw the bracelets on his sister’s wrists and the nose ring and heard his sister Rebekah say, “This is what the man said to me,” he went out to meet the man. There he was, standing by the camels near the spring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said to him, “Come, you who are blessed by the Lord! Why are you standing out here when I have prepared the house and a place for the camels?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abraham’s servant went to the house and unloaded the camels. Straw and feed were given to the camels, and water was provided so that he and the men who were with him could wash their feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When food was served, he said, “I will not eat until I have said what I want to say.” “Tell us,” Laban said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am the servant of Abraham,” he began.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord has richly blessed my master and he has become very wealthy. The Lord has given him sheep and cattle, silver and gold, male and female servants, and camels and donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My master’s wife Sarah bore a son to him when she was old, and my master has given him everything he owns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My master made me swear an oath. He said, ‘You must not acquire a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I am living,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but you must go to the family of my father and to my relatives to find a wife for my son.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I said to my master, ‘What if the woman does not want to go with me?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He answered, ‘The Lord, before whom I have walked, will send his angel with you. He will make your journey a success and you will find a wife for my son from among my relatives, from my father’s family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will be free from your oath if you go to my relatives and they will not give her to you. Then you will be free from your oath.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I came to the spring today, I prayed, ‘O Lord, God of my master Abraham, if you have decided to make my journey successful, may events unfold as follows:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here I am, standing by the spring. When the young woman goes out to draw water, I’ll say, “Please give me a little water to drink from your jug.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she will reply to me, “Drink, and I’ll draw water for your camels too.” May that woman be the one whom the Lord has chosen for my master’s son.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Before I finished praying in my heart, along came Rebekah with her water jug on her shoulder! She went down to the spring and drew water. So I said to her, ‘Please give me a drink.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She quickly lowered her jug from her shoulder and said, ‘Drink, and I’ll give your camels water too.’ So I drank, and she also gave the camels water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I asked her, ‘Whose daughter are you?’ She replied, ‘The daughter of Bethuel the son of Nahor, whom Milcah bore to Nahor.’ I put the ring in her nose and the bracelets on her wrists.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I bowed down and worshiped the Lord. I praised the Lord, the God of my master Abraham, who had led me on the right path to find the granddaughter of my master’s brother for his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, if you will show faithful love to my master, tell me. But if not, tell me as well, so that I may go on my way.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Laban and Bethuel replied, “This is the Lord’s doing. Our wishes are of no concern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rebekah stands here before you. Take her and go so that she may become the wife of your master’s son, just as the Lord has decided.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abraham’s servant heard their words, he bowed down to the ground before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he brought out gold, silver jewelry, and clothing and gave them to Rebekah. He also gave valuable gifts to her brother and to her mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After this, he and the men who were with him ate a meal and stayed there overnight.
When they got up in the morning, he said, “Let me leave now so I can return to my master.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Rebekah’s brother and her mother replied, “Let the girl stay with us a few more days, perhaps ten. Then she can go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he said to them, “Don’t detain me—the Lord has granted me success on my journey. Let me leave now so I may return to my master.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said, “We’ll call the girl and find out what she wants to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they called Rebekah and asked her, “Do you want to go with this man?” She replied, “I want to go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they sent their sister Rebekah on her way, accompanied by her female attendant, with Abraham’s servant and his men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They blessed Rebekah with these words:
“Our sister, may you become the mother of thousands of ten thousands!
May your descendants possess the strongholds of their enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rebekah and her female servants mounted the camels and rode away with the man. So Abraham’s servant took Rebekah and left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Isaac came from Beer Lahai Roi, for he was living in the Negev.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went out to relax in the field in the early evening. Then he looked up and saw that there were camels approaching.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rebekah looked up and saw Isaac. She got down from her camel
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and asked Abraham’s servant, “Who is that man walking in the field toward us?” “That is my master,” the servant replied. So she took her veil and covered herself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant told Isaac everything that had happened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Isaac brought Rebekah into his mother Sarah’s tent. He took her as his wife and loved her. So Isaac was comforted after his mother’s death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham had taken another wife, named Keturah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She bore him Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jokshan became the father of Sheba and Dedan. The descendants of Dedan were the Asshurites, Letushites, and Leummites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All these were descendants of Keturah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything he owned Abraham left to his son Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But while he was still alive, Abraham gave gifts to the sons of his concubines and sent them off to the east, away from his son Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abraham lived a total of 175 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abraham breathed his last and died at a good old age, an old man who had lived a full life. He joined his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him in the cave of Machpelah near Mamre, in the field of Ephron the son of Zohar, the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was the field Abraham had purchased from the sons of Heth. There Abraham was buried with his wife Sarah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Abraham’s death, God blessed his son Isaac. Isaac lived near Beer Lahai Roi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the account of Abraham’s son Ishmael, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah’s servant, bore to Abraham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of Ishmael’s sons, by their names according to their records: Nebaioth (Ishmael’s firstborn), Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mishma, Dumah, Massa,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the sons of Ishmael, and these are their names by their settlements and their camps—twelve princes according to their clans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishmael lived a total of 137 years. He breathed his last and died; then he joined his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His descendants settled from Havilah to Shur, which runs next to Egypt all the way to Asshur. They settled away from all their relatives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account of Isaac, the son of Abraham.
Abraham became the father of Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Isaac was forty years old, he married Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel the Aramean from Paddan Aram and sister of Laban the Aramean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac prayed to the Lord on behalf of his wife because she was childless. The Lord answered his prayer, and his wife Rebekah became pregnant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the children struggled inside her, and she said, “Why is this happening to me?” So she asked the Lord,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and the Lord said to her,
“Two nations are in your womb,
and two peoples will be separated from within you.
One people will be stronger than the other,
and the older will serve the younger.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the time came for Rebekah to give birth, there were twins in her womb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The first came out reddish all over, like a hairy garment, so they named him Esau.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his brother came out with his hand clutching Esau’s heel, they named him Jacob. Isaac was sixty years old when they were born.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the boys grew up, Esau became a skilled hunter, a man of the open fields, but Jacob was an even-tempered man, living in tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac loved Esau because he had a taste for fresh game, but Rebekah loved Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Jacob cooked some stew, and when Esau came in from the open fields, he was famished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Esau said to Jacob, “Feed me some of the red stuff—yes, this red stuff—because I’m starving!” (That is why he was also called Edom.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob replied, “First sell me your birthright.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look,” said Esau, “I’m about to die! What use is the birthright to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob said, “Swear an oath to me now.” So Esau swore an oath to him and sold his birthright to Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob gave Esau some bread and lentil stew; Esau ate and drank, then got up and went out. So Esau despised his birthright.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a famine in the land, subsequent to the earlier famine that occurred in the days of Abraham. Isaac went to Abimelech king of the Philistines at Gerar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord appeared to Isaac and said, “Do not go down to Egypt; settle down in the land that I will point out to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Stay in this land. Then I will be with you and will bless you, for I will give all these lands to you and to your descendants, and I will fulfill the solemn promise I made to your father Abraham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will multiply your descendants so they will be as numerous as the stars in the sky, and I will give them all these lands. All the nations of the earth will pronounce blessings on one another using the name of your descendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All this will come to pass because Abraham obeyed me and kept my charge, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Isaac settled in Gerar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the men of that place asked him about his wife, he replied, “She is my sister.” He was afraid to say, “She is my wife,” for he thought to himself, “The men of this place will kill me to get Rebekah because she is very beautiful.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Isaac had been there a long time, Abimelech king of the Philistines happened to look out a window and observed Isaac caressing his wife Rebekah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abimelech summoned Isaac and said, “She is really your wife! Why did you say, ‘She is my sister’?” Isaac replied, “Because I thought someone might kill me to get her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abimelech exclaimed, “What in the world have you done to us? One of the men nearly took your wife to bed, and you would have brought guilt on us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abimelech commanded all the people, “Whoever touches this man or his wife will surely be put to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Isaac planted in that land, he reaped in the same year a hundred times what he had sown, because the Lord blessed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man became wealthy. His influence continued to grow until he became very prominent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had so many sheep and cattle and such a great household of servants that the Philistines became jealous of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Philistines took dirt and filled up all the wells that his father’s servants had dug back in the days of his father Abraham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abimelech said to Isaac, “Leave us and go elsewhere, for you have become much more powerful than we are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Isaac left there and settled in the Gerar Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac reopened the wells that had been dug back in the days of his father Abraham, for the Philistines had stopped them up after Abraham died. Isaac gave these wells the same names his father had given them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Isaac’s servants dug in the valley and discovered a well with fresh flowing water there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the herdsmen of Gerar quarreled with Isaac’s herdsmen, saying, “The water belongs to us!” So Isaac named the well Esek because they argued with him about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His servants dug another well, but they quarreled over it too, so Isaac named it Sitnah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he moved away from there and dug another well. They did not quarrel over it, so Isaac named it Rehoboth, saying, “For now the Lord has made room for us, and we will prosper in the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From there Isaac went up to Beer Sheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord appeared to him that night and said, “I am the God of your father Abraham. Do not be afraid, for I am with you. I will bless you and multiply your descendants for the sake of my servant Abraham.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Isaac built an altar there and worshiped the Lord. He pitched his tent there, and his servants dug a well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Abimelech had come to him from Gerar along with Ahuzzah his friend and Phicol the commander of his army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac asked them, “Why have you come to me? You hate me and sent me away from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They replied, “We could plainly see that the Lord is with you. So we decided there should be a pact between us—between us and you. Allow us to make a treaty with you
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so that you will not do us any harm, just as we have not harmed you, but have always treated you well before sending you away in peace. Now you are blessed by the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Isaac held a feast for them and they celebrated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early in the morning the men made a treaty with each other. Isaac sent them off; they separated on good terms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day Isaac’s servants came and told him about the well they had dug. “We’ve found water,” they reported.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he named it Shibah; that is why the name of the city has been Beer Sheba to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Esau was forty years old, he married Judith the daughter of Beeri the Hittite, as well as Basemath the daughter of Elon the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They caused Isaac and Rebekah great anxiety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Isaac was old and his eyes were so weak that he was almost blind, he called his older son Esau and said to him, “My son!” “Here I am!” Esau replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac said, “Since I am so old, I could die at any time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, take your weapons—your quiver and your bow—and go out into the open fields and hunt down some wild game for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then prepare for me some tasty food, the kind I love, and bring it to me. Then I will eat it so that I may bless you before I die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Rebekah had been listening while Isaac spoke to his son Esau. When Esau went out to the open fields to hunt down some wild game and bring it back,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rebekah said to her son Jacob, “Look, I overheard your father tell your brother Esau,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Bring me some wild game and prepare for me some tasty food. Then I will eat it and bless you in the presence of the Lord before I die.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now then, my son, do exactly what I tell you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go to the flock and get me two of the best young goats. I’ll prepare them in a tasty way for your father, just the way he loves them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you will take it to your father. Thus he will eat it and bless you before he dies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But Esau my brother is a hairy man,” Jacob protested to his mother Rebekah, “and I have smooth skin!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My father may touch me! Then he’ll think I’m mocking him and I’ll bring a curse on myself instead of a blessing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So his mother told him, “Any curse against you will fall on me, my son! Just obey me! Go and get them for me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he went and got the goats and brought them to his mother. She prepared some tasty food, just the way his father loved it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rebekah took her older son Esau’s best clothes, which she had with her in the house, and put them on her younger son Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She put the skins of the young goats on his hands and the smooth part of his neck.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she handed the tasty food and the bread she had made to her son Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went to his father and said, “My father!” Isaac replied, “Here I am. Which are you, my son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to his father, “I am Esau, your firstborn. I’ve done as you told me. Now sit up and eat some of my wild game so that you can bless me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Isaac asked his son, “How in the world did you find it so quickly, my son?” “Because the Lord your God brought it to me,” he replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Come closer so I can touch you, my son, and know for certain if you really are my son Esau.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob went over to his father Isaac, who felt him and said, “The voice is Jacob’s, but the hands are Esau’s.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did not recognize him because his hands were hairy, like his brother Esau’s hands. So Isaac blessed Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he asked, “Are you really my son Esau?” “I am,” Jacob replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac said, “Bring some of the wild game for me to eat, my son. Then I will bless you.” So Jacob brought it to him, and he ate it. He also brought him wine, and Isaac drank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his father Isaac said to him, “Come here and kiss me, my son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Jacob went over and kissed him. When Isaac caught the scent of his clothing, he blessed him, saying,
“Yes, my son smells
like the scent of an open field
which the Lord has blessed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May God give you
the dew of the sky
and the richness of the earth,
and plenty of grain and new wine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May peoples serve you
and nations bow down to you.
You will be lord over your brothers,
and the sons of your mother will bow down to you.
May those who curse you be cursed,
and those who bless you be blessed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac had just finished blessing Jacob, and Jacob had scarcely left his father’s presence, when his brother Esau returned from the hunt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also prepared some tasty food and brought it to his father. Esau said to him, “My father, get up and eat some of your son’s wild game. Then you can bless me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His father Isaac asked, “Who are you?” “I am your firstborn son,” he replied, “Esau!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac began to shake violently and asked, “Then who else hunted game and brought it to me? I ate all of it just before you arrived, and I blessed him. He will indeed be blessed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Esau heard his father’s words, he wailed loudly and bitterly. He said to his father, “Bless me too, my father!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Isaac replied, “Your brother came in here deceitfully and took away your blessing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau exclaimed, “Jacob is the right name for him! He has tripped me up two times! He took away my birthright, and now, look, he has taken away my blessing!” Then he asked, “Have you not kept back a blessing for me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac replied to Esau, “Look! I have made him lord over you. I have made all his relatives his servants and provided him with grain and new wine. What is left that I can do for you, my son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau said to his father, “Do you have only that one blessing, my father? Bless me too!” Then Esau wept loudly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So his father Isaac said to him,
“See here, your home will be by the richness of the earth,
and by the dew of the sky above.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will live by your sword
but you will serve your brother.
When you grow restless,
you will tear off his yoke
from your neck.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing his father had given to his brother. Esau said privately, “The time of mourning for my father is near; then I will kill my brother Jacob!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rebekah heard what her older son Esau had said, she quickly summoned her younger son Jacob and told him, “Look, your brother Esau is planning to get revenge by killing you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now then, my son, do what I say. Run away immediately to my brother Laban in Haran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Live with him for a little while until your brother’s rage subsides.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Stay there until your brother’s anger against you subsides and he forgets what you did to him. Then I’ll send someone to bring you back from there. Why should I lose both of you in one day?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rebekah said to Isaac, “I am deeply depressed because of the daughters of Heth. If Jacob were to marry one of these daughters of Heth who live in this land, I would want to die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Isaac called for Jacob and blessed him. Then he commanded him, “You must not marry a Canaanite woman!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leave immediately for Paddan Aram! Go to the house of Bethuel, your mother’s father, and find yourself a wife there, among the daughters of Laban, your mother’s brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Sovereign God bless you! May he make you fruitful and give you a multitude of descendants! Then you will become a large nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May he give you and your descendants the blessing he gave to Abraham so that you may possess the land God gave to Abraham, the land where you have been living as a temporary resident.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Isaac sent Jacob on his way, and he went to Paddan Aram, to Laban son of Bethuel the Aramean and brother of Rebekah, the mother of Jacob and Esau.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau saw that Isaac had blessed Jacob and sent him off to Paddan Aram to find a wife there. As he blessed him, Isaac commanded him, “You must not marry a Canaanite woman.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob obeyed his father and mother and left for Paddan Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Esau realized that the Canaanite women were displeasing to his father Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Esau went to Ishmael and married Mahalath, the sister of Nebaioth and daughter of Abraham’s son Ishmael, along with the wives he already had.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile Jacob left Beer Sheba and set out for Haran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He reached a certain place where he decided to camp because the sun had gone down. He took one of the stones and placed it near his head. Then he fell asleep in that place
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and had a dream. He saw a stairway erected on the earth with its top reaching to the heavens. The angels of God were going up and coming down it
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Lord stood at its top. He said, “I am the Lord, the God of your grandfather Abraham and the God of your father Isaac. I will give you and your descendants the ground you are lying on.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your descendants will be like the dust of the earth, and you will spread out to the west, east, north, and south. And so all the families of the earth may receive blessings through you and through your descendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am with you! I will protect you wherever you go and will bring you back to this land. I will not leave you until I have done what I promised you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob woke up and thought, “Surely the Lord is in this place, but I did not realize it!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was afraid and said, “What an awesome place this is! This is nothing else than the house of God! This is the gate of heaven!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early in the morning Jacob took the stone he had placed near his head and set it up as a sacred stone. Then he poured oil on top of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He called that place Bethel, although the former name of the town was Luz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob made a vow, saying, “If God is with me and protects me on this journey I am taking and gives me food to eat and clothing to wear,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I return safely to my father’s home, then the Lord will become my God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this stone that I have set up as a sacred stone will be the house of God, and I will surely give you back a tenth of everything you give me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob moved on and came to the land of the eastern people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He saw in the field a well with three flocks of sheep lying beside it, because the flocks were watered from that well. Now a large stone covered the mouth of the well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the flocks were gathered there, the shepherds would roll the stone off the mouth of the well and water the sheep. Then they would put the stone back in its place over the well’s mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob asked them, “My brothers, where are you from?” They replied, “We’re from Haran.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he said to them, “Do you know Laban, the grandson of Nahor?” “We know him,” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Is he well?” Jacob asked. They replied, “He is well. Now look, here comes his daughter Rachel with the sheep.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob said, “Since it is still the middle of the day, it is not time for the flocks to be gathered. You should water the sheep and then go and let them graze some more.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “We can’t,” they said, “until all the flocks are gathered and the stone is rolled off the mouth of the well. Then we water the sheep.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was still speaking with them, Rachel arrived with her father’s sheep, for she was tending them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob saw Rachel, the daughter of his uncle Laban, and the sheep of his uncle Laban, he went over and rolled the stone off the mouth of the well and watered the sheep of his uncle Laban.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob kissed Rachel and began to weep loudly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob explained to Rachel that he was a relative of her father and the son of Rebekah, she ran and told her father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Laban heard this news about Jacob, his sister’s son, he rushed out to meet him. He embraced him and kissed him and brought him to his house. Jacob told Laban how he was related to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Laban said to him, “You are indeed my own flesh and blood.” So Jacob stayed with him for a month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Laban said to Jacob, “Should you work for me for nothing because you are my relative? Tell me what your wages should be.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now Laban had two daughters; the older one was named Leah, and the younger one Rachel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah’s eyes were tender, but Rachel had a lovely figure and beautiful appearance.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since Jacob had fallen in love with Rachel, he said, “I’ll serve you seven years in exchange for your younger daughter Rachel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban replied, “I’d rather give her to you than to another man. Stay with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob worked for seven years to acquire Rachel. But they seemed like only a few days to him because his love for her was so great.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Finally Jacob said to Laban, “Give me my wife, for my time of service is up. And I want to sleep with her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Laban invited all the people of that place and prepared a feast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the evening he brought his daughter Leah to Jacob, and he slept with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Laban gave his female servant Zilpah to his daughter Leah to be her servant.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning Jacob discovered it was Leah! So Jacob said to Laban, “What in the world have you done to me? Didn’t I work for you in exchange for Rachel? Why have you tricked me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “It is not our custom here,” Laban replied, “to give the younger daughter in marriage before the firstborn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Complete my older daughter’s bridal week. Then we will give you the younger one too, in exchange for seven more years of work.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob did as Laban said. When Jacob completed Leah’s bridal week, Laban gave him his daughter Rachel to be his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Laban gave his female servant Bilhah to his daughter Rachel to be her servant.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob slept with Rachel as well. He also loved Rachel more than Leah. Then he worked for Laban for seven more years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord saw that Leah was unloved, he enabled her to become pregnant while Rachel remained childless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Leah became pregnant and gave birth to a son. She named him Reuben, for she said, “The Lord has looked with pity on my oppressed condition. Surely my husband will love me now.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She became pregnant again and had another son. She said, “Because the Lord heard that I was unloved, he gave me this one too.” So she named him Simeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She became pregnant again and had another son. She said, “Now this time my husband will show me affection, because I have given birth to three sons for him.” That is why he was named Levi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She became pregnant again and had another son. She said, “This time I will praise the Lord.” That is why she named him Judah. Then she stopped having children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rachel saw that she could not give Jacob children, she became jealous of her sister. She said to Jacob, “Give me children or I’ll die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob became furious with Rachel and exclaimed, “Am I in the place of God, who has kept you from having children?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She replied, “Here is my servant Bilhah! Sleep with her so that she can bear children for me and I can have a family through her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Rachel gave him her servant Bilhah as a wife, and Jacob slept with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bilhah became pregnant and gave Jacob a son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rachel said, “God has vindicated me. He has responded to my prayer and given me a son.” That is why she named him Dan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bilhah, Rachel’s servant, became pregnant again and gave Jacob another son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rachel said, “I have fought a desperate struggle with my sister, but I have won.” So she named him Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Leah saw that she had stopped having children, she gave her servant Zilpah to Jacob as a wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Soon Leah’s servant Zilpah gave Jacob a son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah said, “How fortunate!” So she named him Gad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Leah’s servant Zilpah gave Jacob another son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah said, “How happy I am, for women will call me happy!” So she named him Asher.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the time of the wheat harvest Reuben went out and found some mandrake plants in a field and brought them to his mother Leah. Rachel said to Leah, “Give me some of your son’s mandrakes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Leah replied, “Wasn’t it enough that you’ve taken away my husband? Would you take away my son’s mandrakes too?” “All right,” Rachel said, “he may go to bed with you tonight in exchange for your son’s mandrakes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob came in from the fields that evening, Leah went out to meet him and said, “You must sleep with me because I have paid for your services with my son’s mandrakes.” So he went to bed with her that night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God paid attention to Leah; she became pregnant and gave Jacob a son for the fifth time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Leah said, “God has granted me a reward because I gave my servant to my husband as a wife.” So she named him Issachar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Leah became pregnant again and gave Jacob a son for the sixth time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Leah said, “God has given me a good gift. Now my husband will honor me because I have given him six sons.” So she named him Zebulun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After that she gave birth to a daughter and named her Dinah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God took note of Rachel. He paid attention to her and enabled her to become pregnant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She became pregnant and gave birth to a son. Then she said, “God has taken away my shame.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She named him Joseph, saying, “May the Lord give me yet another son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Rachel had given birth to Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, “Send me on my way so that I can go home to my own country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let me take my wives and my children whom I have acquired by working for you. Then I’ll depart, because you know how hard I’ve worked for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Laban said to him, “If I have found favor in your sight, please stay here, for I have learned by divination that the Lord has blessed me on account of you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He added, “Just name your wages—I’ll pay whatever you want.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You know how I have worked for you,” Jacob replied, “and how well your livestock have fared under my care.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, you had little before I arrived, but now your possessions have increased many times over. The Lord has blessed you wherever I worked. But now, how long must it be before I do something for my own family too?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Laban asked, “What should I give you?” “You don’t need to give me a thing,” Jacob replied, “but if you agree to this one condition, I will continue to care for your flocks and protect them:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let me walk among all your flocks today and remove from them every speckled or spotted sheep, every dark-colored lamb, and the spotted or speckled goats. These animals will be my wages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My integrity will testify for me later on. When you come to verify that I’ve taken only the wages we agreed on, if I have in my possession any goat that is not speckled or spotted or any sheep that is not dark-colored, it will be considered stolen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Agreed!” said Laban, “It will be as you say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So that day Laban removed the male goats that were streaked or spotted, all the female goats that were speckled or spotted (all that had any white on them), and all the dark-colored lambs, and put them in the care of his sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he separated them from Jacob by a three-day journey, while Jacob was taking care of the rest of Laban’s flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob took fresh-cut branches from poplar, almond, and plane trees. He made white streaks by peeling them, making the white inner wood in the branches visible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he set up the peeled branches in all the watering troughs where the flocks came to drink. He set up the branches in front of the flocks when they were in heat and came to drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sheep mated in front of the branches, they gave birth to young that were streaked or speckled or spotted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob removed these lambs, but he made the rest of the flock face the streaked and completely dark-colored animals in Laban’s flock. So he made separate flocks for himself and did not mix them with Laban’s flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the stronger females were in heat, Jacob would set up the branches in the troughs in front of the flock, so they would mate near the branches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the animals were weaker, he did not set the branches there. So the weaker animals ended up belonging to Laban and the stronger animals to Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way Jacob became extremely prosperous. He owned large flocks, male and female servants, camels, and donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob heard that Laban’s sons were complaining, “Jacob has taken everything that belonged to our father! He has gotten rich at our father’s expense!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob saw the look on Laban’s face, he could tell his attitude toward him had changed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Jacob, “Return to the land of your fathers and to your relatives. I will be with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob sent a message for Rachel and Leah to come to the field where his flocks were.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There he said to them, “I can tell that your father’s attitude toward me has changed, but the God of my father has been with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know that I’ve worked for your father as hard as I could,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but your father has humiliated me and changed my wages ten times. But God has not permitted him to do me any harm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he said, ‘The speckled animals will be your wage,’ then the entire flock gave birth to speckled offspring. But if he said, ‘The streaked animals will be your wage,’ then the entire flock gave birth to streaked offspring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way God has snatched away your father’s livestock and given them to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Once during breeding season I saw in a dream that the male goats mating with the flock were streaked, speckled, and spotted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the dream the angel of God said to me, ‘Jacob!’ ‘Here I am!’ I replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said, ‘Observe that all the male goats mating with the flock are streaked, speckled, or spotted, for I have observed all that Laban has done to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am the God of Bethel, where you anointed the sacred stone and made a vow to me. Now leave this land immediately and return to your native land.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Rachel and Leah replied to him, “Do we still have any portion or inheritance in our father’s house?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hasn’t he treated us like foreigners? He not only sold us, but completely wasted the money paid for us!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Surely all the wealth that God snatched away from our father belongs to us and to our children. So now do everything God has told you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob immediately put his children and his wives on the camels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took away all the livestock he had acquired in Paddan Aram and all his moveable property that he had accumulated. Then he set out toward the land of Canaan to return to his father Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Laban had gone to shear his sheep, Rachel stole the household idols that belonged to her father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob also deceived Laban the Aramean by not telling him that he was leaving.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He left with all he owned. He quickly crossed the Euphrates River and headed for the hill country of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days later Laban discovered Jacob had left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he took his relatives with him and pursued Jacob for seven days. He caught up with him in the hill country of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God came to Laban the Aramean in a dream at night and warned him, “Be careful that you neither bless nor curse Jacob.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban overtook Jacob, and when Jacob pitched his tent in the hill country of Gilead, Laban and his relatives set up camp there too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What have you done?” Laban demanded of Jacob. “You’ve deceived me and carried away my daughters as if they were captives of war!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why did you run away secretly and deceive me? Why didn’t you tell me so I could send you off with a celebration complete with singing, tambourines, and harps?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You didn’t even allow me to kiss my daughters and my grandchildren goodbye. You have acted foolishly!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have the power to do you harm, but the God of your father told me last night, ‘Be careful that you neither bless nor curse Jacob.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I understand that you have gone away because you longed desperately for your father’s house. Yet why did you steal my gods?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I left secretly because I was afraid!” Jacob replied to Laban. “I thought you might take your daughters away from me by force.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever has taken your gods will be put to death! In the presence of our relatives identify whatever is yours and take it.” (Now Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen them.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Laban entered Jacob’s tent, and Leah’s tent, and the tent of the two female servants, but he did not find the idols. Then he left Leah’s tent and entered Rachel’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now Rachel had taken the idols and put them inside her camel’s saddle and sat on them.) Laban searched the whole tent, but did not find them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rachel said to her father, “Don’t be angry, my lord. I cannot stand up in your presence because I am having my period.” So he searched thoroughly, but did not find the idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob became angry and argued with Laban. “What did I do wrong?” he demanded of Laban. “What sin of mine prompted you to chase after me in hot pursuit?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you searched through all my goods, did you find anything that belonged to you? Set it here before my relatives and yours, and let them settle the dispute between the two of us!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I have been with you for the past twenty years. Your ewes and female goats have not miscarried, nor have I eaten rams from your flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Animals torn by wild beasts I never brought to you; I always absorbed the loss myself. You always made me pay for every missing animal, whether it was taken by day or at night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I was consumed by scorching heat during the day and by piercing cold at night, and I went without sleep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was my lot for twenty years in your house: I worked like a slave for you—fourteen years for your two daughters and six years for your flocks—but you changed my wages ten times!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the God of my father—the God of Abraham, the one whom Isaac fears—had not been with me, you would certainly have sent me away empty-handed! But God saw how I was oppressed and how hard I worked, and he rebuked you last night.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban replied to Jacob, “These women are my daughters, these children are my grandchildren, and these flocks are my flocks. All that you see belongs to me. But how can I harm these daughters of mine today or the children to whom they have given birth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now, come, let’s make a formal agreement, you and I, and it will be proof that we have made peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob took a stone and set it up as a memorial pillar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to his relatives, “Gather stones.” So they brought stones and put them in a pile. They ate there by the pile of stones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban called it Jegar Sahadutha, but Jacob called it Galeed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Laban said, “This pile of stones is a witness of our agreement today.” That is why it was called Galeed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was also called Mizpah because he said, “May the Lord watch between us when we are out of sight of one another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you mistreat my daughters or if you take wives besides my daughters, although no one else is with us, realize that God is witness to your actions.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Here is this pile of stones and this pillar I have set up between me and you,” Laban said to Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This pile of stones and the pillar are reminders that I will not pass beyond this pile to come to harm you and that you will not pass beyond this pile and this pillar to come to harm me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the God of Abraham and the god of Nahor, the gods of their father, judge between us.” Jacob took an oath by the God whom his father Isaac feared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob offered a sacrifice on the mountain and invited his relatives to eat the meal. They ate the meal and spent the night on the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (32:1) Early in the morning Laban kissed his grandchildren and his daughters goodbye and blessed them. Then Laban left and returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob went on his way and the angels of God met him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob saw them, he exclaimed, “This is the camp of God!” So he named that place Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob sent messengers on ahead to his brother Esau in the land of Seir, the region of Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He commanded them, “This is what you must say to my lord Esau: ‘This is what your servant Jacob says: I have been staying with Laban until now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have oxen, donkeys, sheep, and male and female servants. I have sent this message to inform my lord, so that I may find favor in your sight.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messengers returned to Jacob and said, “We went to your brother Esau. He is coming to meet you and has 400 men with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob was very afraid and upset. So he divided the people who were with him into two camps, as well as the flocks, herds, and camels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “If Esau attacks one camp,” he thought, “then the other camp will be able to escape.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob prayed, “O God of my father Abraham, God of my father Isaac, O Lord, you said to me, ‘Return to your land and to your relatives and I will make you prosper.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am not worthy of all the faithful love you have shown your servant. With only my walking stick I crossed the Jordan, but now I have become two camps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rescue me, I pray, from the hand of my brother Esau, for I am afraid he will come and attack me, as well as the mothers with their children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you said, ‘I will certainly make you prosper and will make your descendants like the sand on the seashore, too numerous to count.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob stayed there that night. Then he sent as a gift to his brother Esau
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 200 female goats and 20 male goats, 200 ewes and 20 rams,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 30 female camels with their young, 40 cows and 10 bulls, and 20 female donkeys and 10 male donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He entrusted them to his servants, who divided them into herds. He told his servants, “Pass over before me, and keep some distance between one herd and the next.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He instructed the servant leading the first herd, “When my brother Esau meets you and asks, ‘To whom do you belong? Where are you going? Whose herds are you driving?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then you must say, ‘They belong to your servant Jacob. They have been sent as a gift to my lord Esau. In fact Jacob himself is behind us.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also gave these instructions to the second and third servants, as well as all those who were following the herds, saying, “You must say the same thing to Esau when you meet him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must also say, ‘In fact your servant Jacob is behind us.’” Jacob thought, “I will first appease him by sending a gift ahead of me. After that I will meet him. Perhaps he will accept me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the gifts were sent on ahead of him while he spent that night in the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the night Jacob quickly took his two wives, his two female servants, and his eleven sons and crossed the ford of the Jabbok.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took them and sent them across the stream along with all his possessions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob was left alone. Then a man wrestled with him until daybreak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the man saw that he could not defeat Jacob, he struck the socket of his hip so the socket of Jacob’s hip was dislocated while he wrestled with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man said, “Let me go, for the dawn is breaking.” “I will not let you go,” Jacob replied, “unless you bless me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man asked him, “What is your name?” He answered, “Jacob.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No longer will your name be Jacob,” the man told him, “but Israel, because you have fought with God and with men and have prevailed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob asked, “Please tell me your name.” “Why do you ask my name?” the man replied. Then he blessed Jacob there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob named the place Peniel, explaining, “Certainly I have seen God face to face and have survived.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sun rose over him as he crossed over Penuel, but he was limping because of his hip.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is why to this day the Israelites do not eat the sinew which is attached to the socket of the hip, because he struck the socket of Jacob’s hip near the attached sinew.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob looked up and saw that Esau was coming along with 400 men. So he divided the children among Leah, Rachel, and the two female servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put the servants and their children in front, with Leah and her children behind them, and Rachel and Joseph behind them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob himself went on ahead of them, and he bowed toward the ground seven times as he approached his brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Esau ran to meet him, embraced him, hugged his neck, and kissed him. Then they both wept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Esau looked up and saw the women and the children, he asked, “Who are these people with you?” Jacob replied, “The children whom God has graciously given your servant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The female servants came forward with their children and bowed down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Leah came forward with her children and they bowed down. Finally Joseph and Rachel came forward and bowed down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau then asked, “What did you intend by sending all these herds to meet me?” Jacob replied, “To find favor in your sight, my lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Esau said, “I have plenty, my brother. Keep what belongs to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No, please take them,” Jacob said. “If I have found favor in your sight, accept my gift from my hand. Now that I have seen your face and you have accepted me, it is as if I have seen the face of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please take my present that was brought to you, for God has been generous to me and I have all I need.” When Jacob urged him, he took it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Esau said, “Let’s be on our way! I will go in front of you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob said to him, “My lord knows that the children are young, and that I have to look after the sheep and cattle that are nursing their young. If they are driven too hard for even a single day, all the animals will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let my lord go on ahead of his servant. I will travel more slowly, at the pace of the herds and the children, until I come to my lord at Seir.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Esau said, “Let me leave some of my men with you.” “Why do that?” Jacob replied. “My lord has already been kind enough to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So that same day Esau made his way back to Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob traveled to Sukkoth where he built himself a house and made shelters for his livestock. That is why the place was called Sukkoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he left Paddan Aram, Jacob came safely to the city of Shechem in the land of Canaan, and he camped near the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he purchased the portion of the field where he had pitched his tent; he bought it from the sons of Hamor, Shechem’s father, for 100 pieces of money.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There he set up an altar and called it “The God of Israel is God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Dinah, Leah’s daughter whom she bore to Jacob, went to meet the young women of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Shechem son of Hamor the Hivite, who ruled that area, saw her, he grabbed her, forced himself on her, and sexually assaulted her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he became very attached to Dinah, Jacob’s daughter. He fell in love with the young woman and spoke romantically to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shechem said to his father Hamor, “Acquire this young girl as my wife.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob heard that Shechem had violated his daughter Dinah, his sons were with the livestock in the field. So Jacob remained silent until they came in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Shechem’s father Hamor went to speak with Jacob about Dinah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Jacob’s sons had come in from the field when they heard the news. They were offended and very angry because Shechem had disgraced Israel by sexually assaulting Jacob’s daughter, a crime that should not be committed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Hamor made this appeal to them: “My son Shechem is in love with your daughter. Please give her to him as his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Intermarry with us. Let us marry your daughters, and take our daughters as wives for yourselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You may live among us, and the land will be open to you. Live in it, travel freely in it, and acquire property in it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Shechem said to Dinah’s father and brothers, “Let me find favor in your sight, and whatever you require of me I’ll give.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You can make the bride price and the gift I must bring very expensive, and I’ll give whatever you ask of me. Just give me the young woman as my wife!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob’s sons answered Shechem and his father Hamor deceitfully when they spoke because Shechem had violated their sister Dinah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to them, “We cannot give our sister to a man who is not circumcised, for it would be a disgrace to us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will give you our consent on this one condition: You must become like us by circumcising all your males.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then we will give you our daughters to marry, and we will take your daughters as wives for ourselves, and we will live among you and become one people.
verses.speaker: Narrator
