verses.text: But if you do not agree to our terms by being circumcised, then we will take our sister and depart.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their offer pleased Hamor and his son Shechem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young man did not delay in doing what they asked because he wanted Jacob’s daughter Dinah badly. (Now he was more important than anyone in his father’s household.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hamor and his son Shechem went to the gate of their city and spoke to the men of their city,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “These men are at peace with us. So let them live in the land and travel freely in it, for the land is wide enough for them. We will take their daughters for wives, and we will give them our daughters to marry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Only on this one condition will these men consent to live with us and become one people: They demand that every male among us be circumcised just as they are circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If we do so, won’t their livestock, their property, and all their animals become ours? So let’s consent to their demand, so they will live among us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the men who assembled at the city gate agreed with Hamor and his son Shechem. Every male who assembled at the city gate was circumcised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In three days, when they were still in pain, two of Jacob’s sons, Simeon and Levi, Dinah’s brothers, each took his sword and went to the unsuspecting city and slaughtered every male.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They killed Hamor and his son Shechem with the sword, took Dinah from Shechem’s house, and left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob’s sons killed them and looted the city because their sister had been violated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took their flocks, herds, and donkeys, as well as everything in the city and in the surrounding fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They captured as plunder all their wealth, all their little ones, and their wives, including everything in the houses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, “You have brought ruin on me by making me a foul odor among the inhabitants of the land—among the Canaanites and the Perizzites. I am few in number; they will join forces against me and attack me, and both I and my family will be destroyed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Simeon and Levi replied, “Should he treat our sister like a common prostitute?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God said to Jacob, “Go up at once to Bethel and live there. Make an altar there to God, who appeared to you when you fled from your brother Esau.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob told his household and all who were with him, “Get rid of the foreign gods you have among you. Purify yourselves and change your clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let us go up at once to Bethel. Then I will make an altar there to God, who responded to me in my time of distress and has been with me wherever I went.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they gave Jacob all the foreign gods that were in their possession and the rings that were in their ears. Jacob buried them under the oak near Shechem
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and they started on their journey. The surrounding cities were afraid of God, and they did not pursue the sons of Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob and all those who were with him arrived at Luz (that is, Bethel) in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built an altar there and named the place El Bethel because there God had revealed himself to him when he was fleeing from his brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Deborah, Rebekah’s nurse, died and was buried under the oak below Bethel; thus it was named Oak of Weeping.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God appeared to Jacob again after he returned from Paddan Aram and blessed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to him, “Your name is Jacob, but your name will no longer be called Jacob; Israel will be your name.” So God named him Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God said to him, “I am the Sovereign God. Be fruitful and multiply! A nation—even a company of nations—will descend from you; kings will be among your descendants!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The land I gave to Abraham and Isaac I will give to you. To your descendants I will also give this land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God went up from the place where he spoke with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob set up a sacred stone pillar in the place where God spoke with him. He poured out a drink offering on it, and then he poured oil on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob named the place where God spoke with him Bethel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They traveled on from Bethel, and when Ephrath was still some distance away, Rachel went into labor—and her labor was hard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When her labor was at its hardest, the midwife said to her, “Don’t be afraid, for you are having another son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With her dying breath, she named him Ben Oni. But his father called him Benjamin instead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob set up a marker over her grave; it is the Marker of Rachel’s Grave to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Israel traveled on and pitched his tent beyond Migdal Eder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
While Israel was living in that land, Reuben went to bed with Bilhah, his father’s concubine, and Israel heard about it.
Jacob had twelve sons:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Leah were Reuben, Jacob’s firstborn, as well as Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Rachel were Joseph and Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Bilhah, Rachel’s servant, were Dan and Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Zilpah, Leah’s servant, were Gad and Asher. 
These were the sons of Jacob who were born to him in Paddan Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob came back to his father Isaac in Mamre, to Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac had stayed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isaac lived to be 180 years old.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Isaac breathed his last and joined his ancestors. He died an old man who had lived a full life. His sons Esau and Jacob buried him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What follows is the account of Esau (also known as Edom).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau took his wives from the Canaanites: Adah the daughter of Elon the Hittite, and Oholibamah the daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon the Hivite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: in addition to Basemath the daughter of Ishmael and sister of Nebaioth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adah bore Eliphaz to Esau, Basemath bore Reuel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Oholibamah bore Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These were the sons of Esau who were born to him in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Esau took his wives, his sons, his daughters, all the people in his household, his livestock, his animals, and all his possessions that he had acquired in the land of Canaan, and he went to a land some distance away from Jacob his brother
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because they had too many possessions to be able to stay together, and the land where they had settled was not able to support them because of their livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Esau (also known as Edom) lived in the hill country of Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the account of Esau, the father of the Edomites, in the hill country of Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the names of Esau’s sons: Eliphaz, the son of Esau’s wife Adah, and Reuel, the son of Esau’s wife Basemath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Eliphaz: Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Timna, a concubine of Esau’s son Eliphaz, bore Amalek to Eliphaz. These were the sons of Esau’s wife Adah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Reuel: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the sons of Esau’s wife Basemath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Esau’s wife Oholibamah the daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon: She bore Jeush, Jalam, and Korah to Esau.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the chiefs among the descendants of Esau, the sons of Eliphaz, Esau’s firstborn: chief Teman, chief Omar, chief Zepho, chief Kenaz,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: chief Korah, chief Gatam, chief Amalek. These were the chiefs descended from Eliphaz in the land of Edom; these were the sons of Adah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Esau’s son Reuel: chief Nahath, chief Zerah, chief Shammah, chief Mizzah. These were the chiefs descended from Reuel in the land of Edom; these were the sons of Esau’s wife Basemath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Esau’s wife Oholibamah: chief Jeush, chief Jalam, chief Korah. These were the chiefs descended from Esau’s wife Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Esau (also known as Edom), and these were their chiefs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Seir the Horite, who were living in the land: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These were the chiefs of the Horites, the descendants of Seir in the land of Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Lotan were Hori and Homam; Lotan’s sister was Timna.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Shobal: Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah (who discovered the hot springs in the wilderness as he pastured the donkeys of his father Zibeon).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the children of Anah: Dishon and Oholibamah, the daughter of Anah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Dishon: Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Keran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Ezer: Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Dishan: Uz and Aran.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the chiefs of the Horites: chief Lotan, chief Shobal, chief Zibeon, chief Anah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: chief Dishon, chief Ezer, chief Dishan. These were the chiefs of the Horites, according to their chief lists in the land of Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the kings who reigned in the land of Edom before any king ruled over the Israelites:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bela the son of Beor reigned in Edom; the name of his city was Dinhabah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Bela died, Jobab the son of Zerah from Bozrah reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jobab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Husham died, Hadad the son of Bedad, who defeated the Midianites in the land of Moab, reigned in his place; the name of his city was Avith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hadad died, Samlah from Masrekah reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Samlah died, Shaul from Rehoboth on the River reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Shaul died, Baal Hanan the son of Achbor reigned in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Baal Hanan the son of Achbor died, Hadad reigned in his place; the name of his city was Pau. His wife’s name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, the daughter of Me-Zahab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the names of the chiefs of Esau, according to their families, according to their places, by their names: chief Timna, chief Alvah, chief Jetheth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: chief Oholibamah, chief Elah, chief Pinon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: chief Kenaz, chief Teman, chief Mibzar,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: chief Magdiel, chief Iram. These were the chiefs of Edom, according to their settlements in the land they possessed. This was Esau, the father of the Edomites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob lived in the land where his father had stayed, in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account of Jacob.
Joseph, his seventeen-year-old son, was taking care of the flocks with his brothers. Now he was a youngster working with the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, his father’s wives. Joseph brought back a bad report about them to their father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Israel loved Joseph more than all his sons because he was a son born to him late in life, and he made a special tunic for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph’s brothers saw that their father loved him more than any of them, they hated Joseph and were not able to speak to him kindly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph had a dream, and when he told his brothers about it they hated him even more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “Listen to this dream I had:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There we were, binding sheaves of grain in the middle of the field. Suddenly my sheaf rose up and stood upright and your sheaves surrounded my sheaf and bowed down to it!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his brothers asked him, “Do you really think you will rule over us or have dominion over us?” They hated him even more because of his dream and because of what he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he had another dream, and told it to his brothers. “Look,” he said. “I had another dream. The sun, the moon, and eleven stars were bowing down to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he told his father and his brothers, his father rebuked him, saying, “What is this dream that you had? Will I, your mother, and your brothers really come and bow down to you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His brothers were jealous of him, but his father kept in mind what Joseph said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his brothers had gone to graze their father’s flocks near Shechem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel said to Joseph, “Your brothers are grazing the flocks near Shechem. Come, I will send you to them.” “I’m ready,” Joseph replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jacob said to him, “Go now and check on the welfare of your brothers and of the flocks, and bring me word.” So Jacob sent him from the valley of Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph reached Shechem, a man found him wandering in the field, so the man asked him, “What are you looking for?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He replied, “I’m looking for my brothers. Please tell me where they are grazing their flocks.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man said, “They left this area, for I heard them say, ‘Let’s go to Dothan.’” So Joseph went after his brothers and found them at Dothan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joseph’s brothers saw him from a distance, and before he reached them, they plotted to kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to one another, “Here comes this master of dreams!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come now, let’s kill him, throw him into one of the cisterns, and then say that a wild animal ate him. Then we’ll see how his dreams turn out!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Reuben heard this, he rescued Joseph from their hands, saying, “Let’s not take his life!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reuben continued, “Don’t shed blood! Throw him into this cistern that is here in the wilderness, but don’t lay a hand on him.” (Reuben said this so he could rescue Joseph from them and take him back to his father.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph reached his brothers, they stripped him of his tunic, the special tunic that he wore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they took him and threw him into the cistern. (Now the cistern was empty; there was no water in it.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they sat down to eat their food, they looked up and saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead. Their camels were carrying spices, balm, and myrrh down to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah said to his brothers, “What profit is there if we kill our brother and cover up his blood?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Come, let’s sell him to the Ishmaelites, but let’s not lay a hand on him, for after all, he is our brother, our own flesh.” His brothers agreed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when the Midianite merchants passed by, Joseph’s brothers pulled him out of the cistern and sold him to the Ishmaelites for twenty pieces of silver. The Ishmaelites then took Joseph to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later Reuben returned to the cistern to find that Joseph was not in it! He tore his clothes,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: returned to his brothers, and said, “The boy isn’t there! And I, where can I go?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took Joseph’s tunic, killed a young goat, and dipped the tunic in the blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they brought the special tunic to their father and said, “We found this. Determine now whether it is your son’s tunic or not.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He recognized it and exclaimed, “It is my son’s tunic! A wild animal has eaten him! Joseph has surely been torn to pieces!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob tore his clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourned for his son many days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All his sons and daughters stood by him to console him, but he refused to be consoled. “No,” he said, “I will go to the grave mourning my son.” So Joseph’s father wept for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now in Egypt the Midianites sold Joseph to Potiphar, one of Pharaoh’s officials, the captain of the guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Judah left his brothers and stayed with an Adullamite man named Hirah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There Judah saw the daughter of a Canaanite man named Shua. Judah acquired her as a wife and slept with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She became pregnant and had a son. Judah named him Er.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She became pregnant again and had another son, whom she named Onan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she had yet another son, whom she named Shelah. She gave birth to him in Kezib.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah acquired a wife for Er his firstborn; her name was Tamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Er, Judah’s firstborn, was evil in the Lord’s sight, so the Lord killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah said to Onan, “Sleep with your brother’s wife and fulfill the duty of a brother-in-law to her so that you may raise up a descendant for your brother.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Onan knew that the child would not be considered his. So whenever he slept with his brother’s wife, he wasted his emission on the ground so as not to give his brother a descendant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What he did was evil in the Lord’s sight, so the Lord killed him too.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah said to his daughter-in-law Tamar, “Live as a widow in your father’s house until Shelah my son grows up.” For he thought, “I don’t want him to die like his brothers.” So Tamar went and lived in her father’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After some time Judah’s wife, the daughter of Shua, died. After Judah was consoled, he left for Timnah to visit his sheepshearers, along with his friend Hirah the Adullamite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tamar was told, “Look, your father-in-law is going up to Timnah to shear his sheep.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she removed her widow’s clothes and covered herself with a veil. She wrapped herself and sat at the entrance to Enaim which is on the way to Timnah. (She did this because she saw that she had not been given to Shelah as a wife, even though he had now grown up.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Judah saw her, he thought she was a prostitute because she had covered her face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He turned aside to her along the road and said, “Come, please, I want to sleep with you.” (He did not realize it was his daughter-in-law.) She asked, “What will you give me so that you may sleep with me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He replied, “I’ll send you a young goat from the flock.” She asked, “Will you give me a pledge until you send it?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “What pledge should I give you?” She replied, “Your seal, your cord, and the staff that’s in your hand.” So he gave them to her, then slept with her, and she became pregnant by him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She left immediately, removed her veil, and put on her widow’s clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah had his friend Hirah the Adullamite take a young goat to get back from the woman the items he had given in pledge, but Hirah could not find her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He asked the men who were there, “Where is the cult prostitute who was at Enaim by the road?” But they replied, “There has been no cult prostitute here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he returned to Judah and said, “I couldn’t find her. Moreover, the men of the place said, ‘There has been no cult prostitute here.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah said, “Let her keep the things for herself. Otherwise we will appear to be dishonest. I did indeed send this young goat, but you couldn’t find her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After three months Judah was told, “Your daughter-in-law Tamar has turned to prostitution, and as a result she has become pregnant.” Judah said, “Bring her out and let her be burned!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were bringing her out, she sent word to her father-in-law: “I am pregnant by the man to whom these belong.” Then she said, “Identify the one to whom the seal, cord, and staff belong.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah recognized them and said, “She is more upright than I am, because I wouldn’t give her to Shelah my son.” He was not physically intimate with her again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was time for her to give birth, there were twins in her womb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While she was giving birth, one child put out his hand, and the midwife took a scarlet thread and tied it on his hand, saying, “This one came out first.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But then he drew back his hand, and his brother came out before him. She said, “How you have broken out of the womb!” So he was named Perez.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward his brother came out—the one who had the scarlet thread on his hand—and he was named Zerah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joseph had been brought down to Egypt. An Egyptian named Potiphar, an official of Pharaoh and the captain of the guard, purchased him from the Ishmaelites who had brought him there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord was with Joseph. He was successful and lived in the household of his Egyptian master.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His master observed that the Lord was with him and that the Lord made everything he was doing successful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph found favor in his sight and became his personal attendant. Potiphar appointed Joseph overseer of his household and put him in charge of everything he owned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From the time Potiphar appointed him over his household and over all that he owned, the Lord blessed the Egyptian’s household for Joseph’s sake. The blessing of the Lord was on everything that he had, both in his house and in his fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Potiphar left everything he had in Joseph’s care; he gave no thought to anything except the food he ate.
Now Joseph was well built and good-looking.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Soon after these things, his master’s wife took notice of Joseph and said, “Come to bed with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he refused, saying to his master’s wife, “Look, my master does not give any thought to his household with me here, and everything that he owns he has put into my care.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is no one greater in this household than I am. He has withheld nothing from me except you because you are his wife. So how could I do such a great evil and sin against God?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even though she continued to speak to Joseph day after day, he did not respond to her invitation to go to bed with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day he went into the house to do his work when none of the household servants were there in the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She grabbed him by his outer garment, saying, “Come to bed with me!” But he left his outer garment in her hand and ran outside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she saw that he had left his outer garment in her hand and had run outside,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: she called for her household servants and said to them, “See, my husband brought in a Hebrew man to us to humiliate us. He tried to go to bed with me, but I screamed loudly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he heard me raise my voice and scream, he left his outer garment beside me and ran outside.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she laid his outer garment beside her until his master came home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what she said to him: “That Hebrew slave you brought to us tried to humiliate me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but when I raised my voice and screamed, he left his outer garment and ran outside.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When his master heard his wife say, “This is the way your slave treated me,” he became furious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph’s master took him and threw him into the prison, the place where the king’s prisoners were confined. So he was there in the prison.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord was with Joseph and showed him kindness. He granted him favor in the sight of the prison warden.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The warden put all the prisoners under Joseph’s care. He was in charge of whatever they were doing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The warden did not concern himself with anything that was in Joseph’s care because the Lord was with him and whatever he was doing the Lord was making successful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After these things happened, the cupbearer to the king of Egypt and the royal baker offended their master, the king of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh was enraged with his two officials, the cupbearer and the baker,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so he imprisoned them in the house of the captain of the guard in the same facility where Joseph was confined.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The captain of the guard appointed Joseph to be their attendant, and he served them.
They spent some time in custody.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Both of them, the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt, who were confined in the prison, had a dream the same night. Each man’s dream had its own meaning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph came to them in the morning, he saw that they were looking depressed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he asked Pharaoh’s officials, who were with him in custody in his master’s house, “Why do you look so sad today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told him, “We both had dreams, but there is no one to interpret them.” Joseph responded, “Don’t interpretations belong to God? Tell them to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the chief cupbearer told his dream to Joseph: “In my dream, there was a vine in front of me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the vine there were three branches. As it budded, its blossoms opened and its clusters ripened into grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Pharaoh’s cup was in my hand, so I took the grapes, squeezed them into his cup, and put the cup in Pharaoh’s hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is its meaning,” Joseph said to him. “The three branches represent three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In three more days Pharaoh will reinstate you and restore you to your office. You will put Pharaoh’s cup in his hand, just as you did before when you were cupbearer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But remember me when it goes well for you, and show me kindness. Make mention of me to Pharaoh and bring me out of this prison,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for I really was kidnapped from the land of the Hebrews and I have done nothing wrong here for which they should put me in a dungeon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the chief baker saw that the interpretation of the first dream was favorable, he said to Joseph, “I also appeared in my dream and there were three baskets of white bread on my head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the top basket there were baked goods of every kind for Pharaoh, but the birds were eating them from the basket that was on my head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph replied, “This is its meaning: The three baskets represent three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In three more days Pharaoh will decapitate you and impale you on a pole. Then the birds will eat your flesh from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day it was Pharaoh’s birthday, so he gave a feast for all his servants. He “lifted up” the head of the chief cupbearer and the head of the chief baker in the midst of his servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He restored the chief cupbearer to his former position so that he placed the cup in Pharaoh’s hand,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but the chief baker he impaled, just as Joseph had predicted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the chief cupbearer did not remember Joseph—he forgot him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of two full years Pharaoh had a dream. As he was standing by the Nile,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: seven fine-looking, fat cows were coming up out of the Nile, and they grazed in the reeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then seven bad-looking, thin cows were coming up after them from the Nile, and they stood beside the other cows at the edge of the river.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The bad-looking, thin cows ate the seven fine-looking, fat cows. Then Pharaoh woke up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he fell asleep again and had a second dream: There were seven heads of grain growing on one stalk, healthy and good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then seven heads of grain, thin and burned by the east wind, were sprouting up after them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The thin heads swallowed up the seven healthy and full heads. Then Pharaoh woke up and realized it was a dream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning he was troubled, so he called for all the diviner-priests of Egypt and all its wise men. Pharaoh told them his dreams, but no one could interpret them for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the chief cupbearer said to Pharaoh, “Today I recall my failures.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh was enraged with his servants, and he put me in prison in the house of the captain of the guards—me and the chief baker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We each had a dream one night; each of us had a dream with its own meaning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a young man, a Hebrew, a servant of the captain of the guards, was with us there. We told him our dreams, and he interpreted the meaning of each of our respective dreams for us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It happened just as he had said to us—Pharaoh restored me to my office, but he impaled the baker.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh summoned Joseph. So they brought him quickly out of the dungeon; he shaved himself, changed his clothes, and came before Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I had a dream, and there is no one who can interpret it. But I have heard about you, that you can interpret dreams.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph replied to Pharaoh, “It is not within my power, but God will speak concerning the welfare of Pharaoh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, “In my dream I was standing by the edge of the Nile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then seven fat and fine-looking cows were coming up out of the Nile, and they grazed in the reeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then seven other cows came up after them; they were scrawny, very bad looking, and lean. I had never seen such bad-looking cows as these in all the land of Egypt!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The lean, bad-looking cows ate up the seven fat cows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had eaten them, no one would have known that they had done so, for they were just as bad-looking as before. Then I woke up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I also saw in my dream seven heads of grain growing on one stalk, full and good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then seven heads of grain, withered and thin and burned with the east wind, were sprouting up after them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The thin heads of grain swallowed up the seven good heads of grain. So I told all this to the diviner-priests, but no one could tell me its meaning.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph said to Pharaoh, “Both dreams of Pharaoh have the same meaning. God has revealed to Pharaoh what he is about to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The seven good cows represent seven years, and the seven good heads of grain represent seven years. Both dreams have the same meaning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The seven lean, bad-looking cows that came up after them represent seven years, as do the seven empty heads of grain burned with the east wind. They represent seven years of famine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is just what I told Pharaoh: God has shown Pharaoh what he is about to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven years of great abundance are coming throughout the whole land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But seven years of famine will occur after them, and all the abundance will be forgotten in the land of Egypt. The famine will devastate the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The previous abundance of the land will not be remembered because of the famine that follows, for the famine will be very severe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The dream was repeated to Pharaoh because the matter has been decreed by God, and God will make it happen soon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So now Pharaoh should look for a wise and discerning man and give him authority over all the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh should do this—he should appoint officials throughout the land to collect one-fifth of the produce of the land of Egypt during the seven years of abundance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They should gather all the excess food during these good years that are coming. By Pharaoh’s authority they should store up grain so the cities will have food, and they should preserve it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This food should be held in storage for the land in preparation for the seven years of famine that will occur throughout the land of Egypt. In this way the land will survive the famine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This advice made sense to Pharaoh and all his officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Pharaoh asked his officials, “Can we find a man like Joseph, one in whom the Spirit of God is present?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Because God has enabled you to know all this, there is no one as wise and discerning as you are!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will oversee my household, and all my people will submit to your commands. Only I, the king, will be greater than you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “See here,” Pharaoh said to Joseph, “I place you in authority over all the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh took his signet ring from his own hand and put it on Joseph’s. He clothed him with fine linen clothes and put a gold chain around his neck.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh had him ride in the chariot used by his second-in-command, and they cried out before him, “Kneel down!” So he placed him over all the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh also said to Joseph, “I am Pharaoh, but without your permission no one will move his hand or his foot in all the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh gave Joseph the name Zaphenath-Paneah. He also gave him Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On, to be his wife. So Joseph took charge of all the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joseph was 30 years old when he began serving Pharaoh king of Egypt. Joseph was commissioned by Pharaoh and was in charge of all the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the seven years of abundance the land produced large, bountiful harvests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph collected all the excess food in the land of Egypt during the seven years and stored it in the cities. In every city he put the food gathered from the fields around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph stored up a vast amount of grain, like the sand of the sea, until he stopped measuring it because it was impossible to measure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two sons were born to Joseph before the famine came. Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On, was their mother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph named the firstborn Manasseh, saying, “Certainly God has made me forget all my trouble and all my father’s house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He named the second child Ephraim, saying, “Certainly God has made me fruitful in the land of my suffering.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The seven years of abundance in the land of Egypt came to an end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the seven years of famine began, just as Joseph had predicted. There was famine in all the other lands, but throughout the land of Egypt there was food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the land of Egypt experienced the famine, the people cried out to Pharaoh for food. Pharaoh said to all the people of Egypt, “Go to Joseph and do whatever he tells you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While the famine was over all the earth, Joseph opened the storehouses and sold grain to the Egyptians. The famine was severe throughout the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People from every country came to Joseph in Egypt to buy grain because the famine was severe throughout the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob heard there was grain in Egypt, he said to his sons, “Why are you looking at each other?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He then said, “Look, I hear that there is grain in Egypt. Go down there and buy grain for us so that we may live and not die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So ten of Joseph’s brothers went down to buy grain from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob did not send Joseph’s brother Benjamin with his brothers, for he said, “What if some accident happens to him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Israel’s sons came to buy grain among the other travelers, for the famine was severe in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Joseph was the ruler of the country, the one who sold grain to all the people of the country. Joseph’s brothers came and bowed down before him with their faces to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph saw his brothers, he recognized them, but he pretended to be a stranger to them and spoke to them harshly. He asked, “Where do you come from?” They answered, “From the land of Canaan, to buy grain for food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph recognized his brothers, but they did not recognize him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph remembered the dreams he had dreamed about them, and he said to them, “You are spies; you have come to see if our land is vulnerable!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they exclaimed, “No, my lord! Your servants have come to buy grain for food!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We are all the sons of one man; we are honest men! Your servants are not spies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No,” he insisted, “but you have come to see if our land is vulnerable.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They replied, “Your servants are from a family of twelve brothers. We are the sons of one man in the land of Canaan. The youngest is with our father at this time, and one is no longer alive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joseph told them, “It is just as I said to you: You are spies!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will be tested in this way: As surely as Pharaoh lives, you will not depart from this place unless your youngest brother comes here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of you must go and get your brother, while the rest of you remain in prison. In this way your words may be tested to see if you are telling the truth. If not, then, as surely as Pharaoh lives, you are spies!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He imprisoned them all for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day Joseph said to them, “Do as I say and you will live, for I fear God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you are honest men, leave one of your brothers confined here in prison while the rest of you go and take grain back for your hungry families.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you must bring your youngest brother to me. Then your words will be verified and you will not die.” They did as he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to one another, “Surely we’re being punished because of our brother, because we saw how distressed he was when he cried to us for mercy, but we refused to listen. That is why this distress has come on us!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reuben said to them, “Didn’t I say to you, ‘Don’t sin against the boy,’ but you wouldn’t listen? So now we must pay for shedding his blood!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now they did not know that Joseph could understand them, for he was speaking through an interpreter.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He turned away from them and wept. When he turned around and spoke to them again, he had Simeon taken from them and tied up before their eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph gave orders to fill their bags with grain, to return each man’s money to his sack, and to give them provisions for the journey. His orders were carried out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they loaded their grain on their donkeys and left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When one of them opened his sack to get feed for his donkey at their resting place, he saw his money in the mouth of his sack.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to his brothers, “My money was returned! Here it is in my sack!” They were dismayed; they turned trembling to one another and said, “What in the world has God done to us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They returned to their father Jacob in the land of Canaan and told him all the things that had happened to them, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The man, the lord of the land, spoke harshly to us and treated us as if we were spying on the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But we said to him, ‘We are honest men; we are not spies!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We are from a family of twelve brothers; we are the sons of one father. One is no longer alive, and the youngest is with our father at this time in the land of Canaan.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then the man, the lord of the land, said to us, ‘This is how I will find out if you are honest men. Leave one of your brothers with me, and take grain for your hungry households and go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But bring your youngest brother back to me so I will know that you are honest men and not spies. Then I will give your brother back to you and you may move about freely in the land.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they were emptying their sacks, there was each man’s bag of money in his sack! When they and their father saw the bags of money, they were afraid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their father Jacob said to them, “You are making me childless! Joseph is gone. Simeon is gone. And now you want to take Benjamin! Everything is against me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Reuben said to his father, “You may put my two sons to death if I do not bring him back to you. Put him in my care and I will bring him back to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jacob replied, “My son will not go down there with you, for his brother is dead and he alone is left. If an accident happens to him on the journey you have to make, then you will bring down my gray hair in sorrow to the grave.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the famine was severe in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they finished eating the grain they had brought from Egypt, their father said to them, “Return, buy us a little more food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Judah said to him, “The man solemnly warned us, ‘You will not see my face unless your brother is with you.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you send our brother with us, we’ll go down and buy food for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you will not send him, we won’t go down there because the man said to us, ‘You will not see my face unless your brother is with you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel said, “Why did you bring this trouble on me by telling the man you had one more brother?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They replied, “The man questioned us thoroughly about ourselves and our family, saying, ‘Is your father still alive? Do you have another brother?’ So we answered him in this way. How could we possibly know that he would say, ‘Bring your brother down’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah said to his father Israel, “Send the boy with me and we will go immediately. Then we will live and not die—we and you and our little ones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I myself pledge security for him; you may hold me liable. If I do not bring him back to you and place him here before you, I will bear the blame before you all my life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if we had not delayed, we could have traveled there and back twice by now!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then their father Israel said to them, “If it must be so, then do this: Take some of the best products of the land in your bags, and take a gift down to the man—a little balm and a little honey, spices and myrrh, pistachios and almonds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take double the money with you; you must take back the money that was returned in the mouths of your sacks—perhaps it was an oversight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take your brother too, and go right away to the man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Sovereign God grant you mercy before the man so that he may release your other brother and Benjamin! As for me, if I lose my children I lose them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the men took these gifts, and they took double the money with them, along with Benjamin. Then they hurried down to Egypt and stood before Joseph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the servant who was over his household, “Bring the men to the house. Slaughter an animal and prepare it, for the men will eat with me at noon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man did just as Joseph said; he brought the men into Joseph’s house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the men were afraid when they were brought to Joseph’s house. They said, “We are being brought in because of the money that was returned in our sacks last time. He wants to capture us, make us slaves, and take our donkeys!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they approached the man who was in charge of Joseph’s household and spoke to him at the entrance to the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “My lord, we did indeed come down the first time to buy food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when we came to the place where we spent the night, we opened our sacks and each of us found his money—the full amount—in the mouth of his sack. So we have returned it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We have brought additional money with us to buy food. We do not know who put the money in our sacks!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Everything is fine,” the man in charge of Joseph’s household told them. “Don’t be afraid. Your God and the God of your father has given you treasure in your sacks. I had your money.” Then he brought Simeon out to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servant in charge brought the men into Joseph’s house. He gave them water, and they washed their feet. Then he gave food to their donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They got their gifts ready for Joseph’s arrival at noon, for they had heard that they were to have a meal there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph came home, they presented him with the gifts they had brought inside, and they bowed down to the ground before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He asked them how they were doing. Then he said, “Is your aging father well, the one you spoke about? Is he still alive?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your servant our father is well,” they replied. “He is still alive.” They bowed down in humility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph looked up and saw his brother Benjamin, his mother’s son, he said, “Is this your youngest brother, whom you told me about?” Then he said, “May God be gracious to you, my son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph hurried out, for he was overcome by affection for his brother and was at the point of tears. So he went to his room and wept there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he washed his face and came out. With composure he said, “Set out the food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They set a place for him, a separate place for his brothers, and another for the Egyptians who were eating with him. (The Egyptians are not able to eat with Hebrews, for the Egyptians think it is disgusting to do so.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sat before him, arranged by order of birth, beginning with the firstborn and ending with the youngest. The men looked at each other in astonishment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He gave them portions of the food set before him, but the portion for Benjamin was five times greater than the portions for any of the others. They drank with Joseph until they all became drunk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He instructed the servant who was over his household, “Fill the sacks of the men with as much food as they can carry and put each man’s money in the mouth of his sack.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then put my cup—the silver cup—in the mouth of the youngest one’s sack, along with the money for his grain.” He did as Joseph instructed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When morning came, the men and their donkeys were sent off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They had not gone very far from the city when Joseph said to the servant who was over his household, “Pursue the men at once! When you overtake them, say to them, ‘Why have you repaid good with evil?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Doesn’t my master drink from this cup and use it for divination? You have done wrong!’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the man overtook them, he spoke these words to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They answered him, “Why does my lord say such things? Far be it from your servants to do such a thing!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, the money that we found in the mouths of our sacks we brought back to you from the land of Canaan. Why then would we steal silver or gold from your master’s house?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If one of us has it, he will die, and the rest of us will become my lord’s slaves!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He replied, “You have suggested your own punishment! The one who has it will become my slave, but the rest of you will go free.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So each man quickly lowered his sack to the ground and opened it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man searched. He began with the oldest and finished with the youngest. The cup was found in Benjamin’s sack!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They all tore their clothes! Then each man loaded his donkey, and they returned to the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Judah and his brothers came back to Joseph’s house. He was still there, and they threw themselves to the ground before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to them, “What did you think you were doing? Don’t you know that a man like me can find out things like this by divination?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah replied, “What can we say to my lord? What can we speak? How can we clear ourselves? God has exposed the sin of your servants! We are now my lord’s slaves, we and the one in whose possession the cup was found.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joseph said, “Far be it from me to do this! The man in whose hand the cup was found will become my slave, but the rest of you may go back to your father in peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Judah approached him and said, “My lord, please allow your servant to speak a word with you. Please do not get angry with your servant, for you are just like Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My lord asked his servants, ‘Do you have a father or a brother?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We said to my lord, ‘We have an aged father, and there is a young boy who was born when our father was old. The boy’s brother is dead. He is the only one of his mother’s sons left, and his father loves him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then you told your servants, ‘Bring him down to me so I can see him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We said to my lord, ‘The boy cannot leave his father. If he leaves his father, his father will die.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you said to your servants, ‘If your youngest brother does not come down with you, you will not see my face again.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When we returned to your servant my father, we told him the words of my lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then our father said, ‘Go back and buy us a little food.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But we replied, ‘We cannot go down there. If our youngest brother is with us, then we will go, for we won’t be permitted to see the man’s face if our youngest brother is not with us.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Then your servant my father said to us, ‘You know that my wife gave me two sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The first disappeared and I said, “He has surely been torn to pieces.” I have not seen him since.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you take this one from me too and an accident happens to him, then you will bring down my gray hair in tragedy to the grave.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So now, when I return to your servant my father, and the boy is not with us—his very life is bound up in his son’s life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he sees the boy is not with us, he will die, and your servants will bring down the gray hair of your servant our father in sorrow to the grave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, your servant pledged security for the boy with my father, saying, ‘If I do not bring him back to you, then I will bear the blame before my father all my life.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So now, please let your servant remain as my lord’s slave instead of the boy. As for the boy, let him go back with his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For how can I go back to my father if the boy is not with me? I couldn’t bear to see my father’s pain.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph was no longer able to control himself before all his attendants, so he cried out, “Make everyone go out from my presence!” No one remained with Joseph when he made himself known to his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He wept loudly; the Egyptians heard it and Pharaoh’s household heard about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to his brothers, “I am Joseph! Is my father still alive?” His brothers could not answer him because they were dumbfounded before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to his brothers, “Come closer to me,” so they came near. Then he said, “I am Joseph your brother, whom you sold into Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, do not be upset and do not be angry with yourselves because you sold me here, for God sent me ahead of you to preserve life!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For these past two years there has been famine in the land and for five more years there will be neither plowing nor harvesting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God sent me ahead of you to preserve you on the earth and to save your lives by a great deliverance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now, it is not you who sent me here, but God. He has made me an adviser to Pharaoh, lord over all his household, and ruler over all the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now go up to my father quickly and tell him, ‘This is what your son Joseph says: “God has made me lord of all Egypt. Come down to me; do not delay!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will live in the land of Goshen, and you will be near me—you, your children, your grandchildren, your flocks, your herds, and everything you have.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will provide you with food there because there will be five more years of famine. Otherwise you would become poor—you, your household, and everyone who belongs to you.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You and my brother Benjamin can certainly see with your own eyes that I really am the one who speaks to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So tell my father about all my honor in Egypt and about everything you have seen. But bring my father down here quickly!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he threw himself on the neck of his brother Benjamin and wept, and Benjamin wept on his neck.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He kissed all his brothers and wept over them. After this his brothers talked with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now it was reported in the household of Pharaoh, “Joseph’s brothers have arrived.” It pleased Pharaoh and his servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Say to your brothers, ‘Do this: Load your animals and go to the land of Canaan!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Get your father and your households and come to me! Then I will give you the best land in Egypt and you will eat the best of the land.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are also commanded to say, ‘Do this: Take for yourselves wagons from the land of Egypt for your little ones and for your wives. Bring your father and come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t worry about your belongings, for the best of all the land of Egypt will be yours.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the sons of Israel did as he said. Joseph gave them wagons as Pharaoh had instructed, and he gave them provisions for the journey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He gave sets of clothes to each one of them, but to Benjamin he gave 300 pieces of silver and five sets of clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To his father he sent the following: ten donkeys loaded with the best products of Egypt and ten female donkeys loaded with grain, food, and provisions for his father’s journey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he sent his brothers on their way and they left. He said to them, “As you travel don’t be overcome with fear.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they went up from Egypt and came to their father Jacob in the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told him, “Joseph is still alive and he is ruler over all the land of Egypt!” Jacob was stunned, for he did not believe them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they related to him everything Joseph had said to them, and when he saw the wagons that Joseph had sent to transport him, their father Jacob’s spirit revived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Israel said, “Enough! My son Joseph is still alive! I will go and see him before I die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Israel began his journey, taking with him all that he had. When he came to Beer Sheba he offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God spoke to Israel in a vision during the night and said, “Jacob, Jacob!” He replied, “Here I am!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “I am God, the God of your father. Do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for I will make you into a great nation there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will go down with you to Egypt and I myself will certainly bring you back from there. Joseph will close your eyes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob started out from Beer Sheba, and the sons of Israel carried their father Jacob, their little children, and their wives in the wagons that Pharaoh had sent along to transport him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob and all his descendants took their livestock and the possessions they had acquired in the land of Canaan, and they went to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought with him to Egypt his sons and grandsons, his daughters and granddaughters—all his descendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Israel who went to Egypt—Jacob and his sons: Reuben, the firstborn of Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Reuben: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Simeon: Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jakin, Zohar, and Shaul (the son of a Canaanite woman).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Judah: Er, Onan, Shelah, Perez, and Zerah (but Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan).
The sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Issachar: Tola, Puah, Jashub, and Shimron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Zebulun: Sered, Elon, and Jahleel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Leah, whom she bore to Jacob in Paddan Aram, along with Dinah his daughter. His sons and daughters numbered thirty-three in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Gad: Zephon, Haggi, Shuni, Ezbon, Eri, Arodi, and Areli.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Asher: Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, Beriah, and Serah their sister.
The sons of Beriah were Heber and Malkiel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to Leah his daughter. She bore these to Jacob, sixteen in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Rachel the wife of Jacob: Joseph and Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh and Ephraim were born to Joseph in the land of Egypt. Asenath daughter of Potiphera, priest of On, bore them to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Benjamin: Bela, Beker, Ashbel, Gera, Naaman, Ehi, Rosh, Muppim, Huppim and Ard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Rachel who were born to Jacob, fourteen in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The son of Dan: Hushim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Naphtali: Jahziel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the sons of Bilhah, whom Laban gave to Rachel his daughter. She bore these to Jacob, seven in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the direct descendants of Jacob who went to Egypt with him were sixty-six in number. (This number does not include the wives of Jacob’s sons.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Counting the two sons of Joseph who were born to him in Egypt, all the people of the household of Jacob who were in Egypt numbered seventy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob sent Judah before him to Joseph to accompany him to Goshen. So they came to the land of Goshen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph harnessed his chariot and went up to meet his father Israel in Goshen. When he met him, he hugged his neck and wept on his neck for quite some time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel said to Joseph, “Now let me die since I have seen your face and know that you are still alive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph said to his brothers and his father’s household, “I will go up and tell Pharaoh, ‘My brothers and my father’s household who were in the land of Canaan have come to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men are shepherds; they take care of livestock. They have brought their flocks and their herds and all that they have.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh will summon you and say, ‘What is your occupation?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell him, ‘Your servants have taken care of cattle from our youth until now, both we and our fathers,’ so that you may live in the land of Goshen, for everyone who takes care of sheep is disgusting to the Egyptians.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph went and told Pharaoh, “My father, my brothers, their flocks and herds, and all that they own have arrived from the land of Canaan. They are now in the land of Goshen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took five of his brothers and introduced them to Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph’s brothers, “What is your occupation?” They said to Pharaoh, “Your servants take care of flocks, just as our ancestors did.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said to Pharaoh, “We have come to live as temporary residents in the land. There is no pasture for your servants’ flocks because the famine is severe in the land of Canaan. So now, please let your servants live in the land of Goshen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Joseph, “Your father and your brothers have come to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The land of Egypt is before you; settle your father and your brothers in the best region of the land. They may live in the land of Goshen. If you know of any highly capable men among them, put them in charge of my livestock.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph brought in his father Jacob and presented him before Pharaoh. Jacob blessed Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Jacob, “How long have you lived?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to Pharaoh, “All the years of my travels are 130. All the years of my life have been few and painful; the years of my travels are not as long as those of my ancestors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jacob blessed Pharaoh and went out from his presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph settled his father and his brothers. He gave them territory in the land of Egypt, in the best region of the land, the land of Rameses, just as Pharaoh had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph also provided food for his father, his brothers, and all his father’s household, according to the number of their little children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But there was no food in all the land because the famine was very severe; the land of Egypt and the land of Canaan wasted away because of the famine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph collected all the money that could be found in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan as payment for the grain they were buying. Then Joseph brought the money into Pharaoh’s palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the money from the lands of Egypt and Canaan was used up, all the Egyptians came to Joseph and said, “Give us food! Why should we die before your very eyes because our money has run out?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph said, “If your money is gone, bring your livestock, and I will give you food in exchange for your livestock.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they brought their livestock to Joseph, and Joseph gave them food in exchange for their horses, the livestock of their flocks and herds, and their donkeys. He got them through that year by giving them food in exchange for all their livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that year was over, they came to him the next year and said to him, “We cannot hide from our lord that the money is used up and the livestock and the animals belong to our lord. Nothing remains before our lord except our bodies and our land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why should we die before your very eyes, both we and our land? Buy us and our land in exchange for food, and we, with our land, will become Pharaoh’s slaves. Give us seed that we may live and not die. Then the land will not become desolate.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph bought all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh. Each of the Egyptians sold his field, for the famine was severe. So the land became Pharaoh’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph made all the people slaves from one end of Egypt’s border to the other end of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he did not purchase the land of the priests because the priests had an allotment from Pharaoh and they ate from their allotment that Pharaoh gave them. That is why they did not sell their land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to the people, “Since I have bought you and your land today for Pharaoh, here is seed for you. Cultivate the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the crop comes in, give one-fifth of it to Pharaoh. The remaining four-fifths will be yours for seed for the fields and for you to eat, including those in your households and your little children.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They replied, “You have saved our lives! You are showing us favor, and we will be Pharaoh’s slaves.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph made it a statute, which is in effect to this day throughout the land of Egypt: One-fifth belongs to Pharaoh. Only the land of the priests did not become Pharaoh’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel settled in the land of Egypt, in the land of Goshen, and they owned land there. They were fruitful and increased rapidly in number.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob lived in the land of Egypt seventeen years; the years of Jacob’s life were 147 in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The time for Israel to die approached, so he called for his son Joseph and said to him, “If now I have found favor in your sight, put your hand under my thigh and show me kindness and faithfulness. Do not bury me in Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but when I rest with my fathers, carry me out of Egypt and bury me in their burial place.” Joseph said, “I will do as you say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said, “Swear to me that you will do so.” So Joseph gave him his word. Then Israel bowed down at the head of his bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After these things Joseph was told, “Your father is weakening.” So he took his two sons Manasseh and Ephraim with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob was told, “Your son Joseph has just come to you,” Israel regained strength and sat up on his bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob said to Joseph, “The Sovereign God appeared to me at Luz in the land of Canaan and blessed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to me, ‘I am going to make you fruitful and will multiply you. I will make you into a group of nations, and I will give this land to your descendants as an everlasting possession.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, as for your two sons, who were born to you in the land of Egypt before I came to you in Egypt, they will be mine. Ephraim and Manasseh will be mine just as Reuben and Simeon are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Any children that you father after them will be yours; they will be listed under the names of their brothers in their inheritance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as for me, when I was returning from Paddan, Rachel died—to my sorrow—in the land of Canaan. It happened along the way, some distance from Ephrath. So I buried her there on the way to Ephrath” (that is, Bethlehem).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Israel saw Joseph’s sons, he asked, “Who are these?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to his father, “They are the sons God has given me in this place.” His father said, “Bring them to me so I may bless them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Israel’s eyes were failing because of his age; he was not able to see well. So Joseph brought his sons near to him, and his father kissed them and embraced them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel said to Joseph, “I never expected to see you again, but now God has allowed me to see your children too.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph moved them from Israel’s knees and bowed down with his face to the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph positioned them; he put Ephraim on his right hand across from Israel’s left hand, and Manasseh on his left hand across from Israel’s right hand. Then Joseph brought them closer to his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel stretched out his right hand and placed it on Ephraim’s head, although he was the younger. Crossing his hands, he put his left hand on Manasseh’s head, for Manasseh was the firstborn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he blessed Joseph and said,
“May the God before whom my fathers
Abraham and Isaac walked—
the God who has been my shepherd
all my life long to this day,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the angel who has protected me
from all harm—
bless these boys.
May my name be named in them,
and the name of my fathers Abraham and Isaac.
May they grow into a multitude on the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph saw that his father placed his right hand on Ephraim’s head, it displeased him. So he took his father’s hand to move it from Ephraim’s head to Manasseh’s head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph said to his father, “Not so, my father, for this is the firstborn. Put your right hand on his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But his father refused and said, “I know, my son, I know. He too will become a nation and he too will become great. In spite of this, his younger brother will be even greater and his descendants will become a multitude of nations.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So he blessed them that day, saying,
“By you will Israel bless, saying,
‘May God make you like Ephraim and Manasseh.’”
Thus he put Ephraim before Manasseh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Israel said to Joseph, “I am about to die, but God will be with you and will bring you back to the land of your fathers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As one who is above your brothers, I give to you the mountain slope, which I took from the Amorites with my sword and my bow.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jacob called for his sons and said, “Gather together so I can tell you what will happen to you in future days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Assemble and listen, you sons of Jacob;
listen to Israel, your father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Reuben, you are my firstborn,
my might and the beginning of my strength,
outstanding in dignity, outstanding in power.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Simeon and Levi are brothers,
weapons of violence are their knives!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O my soul, do not come into their council,
do not be united to their assembly, my heart,
for in their anger they have killed men,
and for pleasure they have hamstrung oxen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Cursed be their anger, for it was fierce,
and their fury, for it was cruel.
I will divide them in Jacob,
and scatter them in Israel!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Judah, your brothers will praise you.
Your hand will be on the neck of your enemies,
your father’s sons will bow down before you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are a lion’s cub, Judah,
from the prey, my son, you have gone up.
He crouches and lies down like a lion;
like a lioness—who will rouse him?
