verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The scepter will not depart from Judah,
nor the ruler’s staff from between his feet,
until he comes to whom it belongs;
the nations will obey him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Binding his foal to the vine,
and his colt to the choicest vine,
he will wash his garments in wine,
his robes in the blood of grapes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His eyes will be red from wine,
and his teeth white from milk.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Issachar is a strong-boned donkey
lying down between two saddlebags.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he sees a good resting place,
and the pleasant land,
he will bend his shoulder to the burden
and become a slave laborer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Dan will judge his people
as one of the tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May Dan be a snake beside the road,
a viper by the path,
that bites the heels of the horse
so that its rider falls backward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I wait for your deliverance, O Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Gad will be raided by marauding bands,
but he will attack them at their heels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Asher’s food will be rich,
and he will provide delicacies to royalty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Naphtali is a free running doe,
he speaks delightful words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Joseph is a fruitful bough,
a fruitful bough near a spring
whose branches climb over the wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The archers will attack him,
they will shoot at him and oppose him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But his bow will remain steady,
and his hands will be skillful;
because of the hands of the Powerful One of Jacob,
because of the Shepherd, the Rock of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because of the God of your father,
who will help you,
because of the Sovereign God,
who will bless you
with blessings from the sky above,
blessings from the deep that lies below,
and blessings of the breasts and womb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The blessings of your father are greater
than the blessings of the eternal mountains
or the desirable things of the age-old hills.
They will be on the head of Joseph
and on the brow of the prince of his brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: These are the twelve tribes of Israel. This is what their father said to them when he blessed them. He gave each of them an appropriate blessing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he instructed them, “I am about to go to my people. Bury me with my fathers in the cave in the field of Ephron the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is the cave in the field of Machpelah, near Mamre in the land of Canaan, which Abraham bought for a burial plot from Ephron the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There they buried Abraham and his wife Sarah; there they buried Isaac and his wife Rebekah; and there I buried Leah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The field and the cave in it were acquired from the sons of Heth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jacob finished giving these instructions to his sons, he pulled his feet up onto the bed, breathed his last breath, and went to his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph hugged his father’s face. He wept over him and kissed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph instructed the physicians in his service to embalm his father, so the physicians embalmed Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took forty days, for that is the full time needed for embalming. The Egyptians mourned for him seventy days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the days of mourning had passed, Joseph said to Pharaoh’s royal court, “If I have found favor in your sight, please say to Pharaoh,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘My father made me swear an oath. He said, “I am about to die. Bury me in my tomb that I dug for myself there in the land of Canaan.” Now let me go and bury my father; then I will return.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Pharaoh said, “Go and bury your father, just as he made you swear to do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph went up to bury his father; all Pharaoh’s officials went with him—the senior courtiers of his household, all the senior officials of the land of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all Joseph’s household, his brothers, and his father’s household. But they left their little children and their flocks and herds in the land of Goshen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Chariots and horsemen also went up with him, so it was a very large entourage.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to the threshing floor of Atad on the other side of the Jordan, they mourned there with very great and bitter sorrow. There Joseph observed a seven-day period of mourning for his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Canaanites who lived in the land saw them mourning at the threshing floor of Atad, they said, “This is a very sad occasion for the Egyptians.” That is why its name was called Abel Mizraim, which is beyond the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the sons of Jacob did for him just as he had instructed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His sons carried him to the land of Canaan and buried him in the cave of the field of Machpelah, near Mamre. This is the field Abraham purchased as a burial plot from Ephron the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he buried his father, Joseph returned to Egypt, along with his brothers and all who had accompanied him to bury his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joseph’s brothers saw that their father was dead, they said, “What if Joseph bears a grudge and wants to repay us in full for all the harm we did to him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they sent word to Joseph, saying, “Your father gave these instructions before he died:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Tell Joseph this: Please forgive the sin of your brothers and the wrong they did when they treated you so badly.’ Now please forgive the sin of the servants of the God of your father.” When this message was reported to him, Joseph wept.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his brothers also came and threw themselves down before him; they said, “Here we are; we are your slaves.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joseph answered them, “Don’t be afraid. Am I in the place of God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for you, you meant to harm me, but God intended it for a good purpose, so he could preserve the lives of many people, as you can see this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now, don’t be afraid. I will provide for you and your little children.” Then he consoled them and spoke kindly to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph lived in Egypt, along with his father’s family. Joseph lived 110 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph saw the descendants of Ephraim to the third generation. He also saw the children of Makir the son of Manasseh; they were given special inheritance rights by Joseph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph said to his brothers, “I am about to die. But God will surely come to you and lead you up from this land to the land he swore on oath to give to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joseph made the sons of Israel swear an oath. He said, “God will surely come to you. Then you must carry my bones up from this place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joseph died at the age of 110. After they embalmed him, his body was placed in a coffin in Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator
